disasters.summary: In March 2023, Afghanistan experienced flooding, an earthquake, and an increase in acute watery diarrhoea (AWD) cases. Schools reopened, but the ban on secondary education for girls remained. UNICEF provided emergency health and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) activities, family tracing and reunification services, and cash transfers to support households with adolescent girls. 28.3 million people and 15.2 million children are in need of humanitarian assistance, and the UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Action for Children (HAC) appeal for 2023 is 22.4 per cent funded. The ban on NGO women humanitarian workers continued to pose challenges, and the de facto Acting Minister of Public Health issued a letter to cease mobile health and nutrition teams (MHNTs).

metadata.name: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Report No. 3: March 2023

disasters.summary: This report forecasts that the number of acutely food insecure people in Sudan will increase by 2-2.5 million in the next 3-6 months if the current conflict continues. It also predicts that West Darfur, West Kordofan, Blue Nile, Red Sea and North Darfur will be the most affected states. Additionally, it is estimated that 800,000 people may flee Sudan and that food prices will increase by 25%, resulting in 18 million people being unable to afford the local food basket.

metadata.name: Conflict in Sudan: Food Security Analysis and Forecast (May 2023)

disasters.summary: This Weekly Bulletin focuses on public health emergencies occurring in the WHO African region, including gastroenteritis in Kenya, measles in South Africa, and mpox in Africa. Major issues and challenges include an outbreak of gastroenteritis in Kakamega County, Kenya, and an ongoing measles outbreak in South Africa. Response measures have been implemented, but there is a need to strengthen routine immunization to prevent future outbreaks.

metadata.name: Weekly Bulletin on Outbreaks and other Emergencies: Week 18: 24-30 April 2023 (Data as reported by: 17:00; 30 April 2023)

disasters.summary: As of 5 May 2023, over 12,000 people have arrived in Metema, West Gondar Zone, from Sudan, with over half of them being Ethiopians. Foreign nationals and Ethiopian returnees are leaving the border area to other destinations, while those who remain require emergency humanitarian assistance. An appeal of US$76.9m has been made for Ethiopia as part of the regional Refugee Response Plan for the situation in Sudan, and health services need to be scaled up to prevent communicable and non-communicable diseases.

metadata.name: Flash Update #2: The Impact of the Situation in Sudan on Ethiopia (As of 5 May 2023)

disasters.summary: In Q1 2023, Kenya has been exposed to a range of natural and man-made disasters, including drought, floods, and epidemics. The Field-Based Preparedness Project is working to strengthen national supply chain resilience and promote a common methodology towards logistics preparedness. During this quarter, the focus has been on project resocialization targeting new county executives and designing logistics preparedness road maps.

metadata.name: Kenya Quarterly Update, (January – March 2023)

disasters.summary: This report covers the period of 18 April to 1 May 2023 in the Occupied Palestinian Territory. During this period, Israeli forces killed two Palestinians, including one child, and injured nine others during two search-and-arrest operations in Jericho. Israeli forces also killed a Palestinian child in Bethlehem, and eight Israelis were injured in three Palestinian attacks in Jerusalem and Ramallah. 166 Palestinians, including at least eight children, were injured by Israeli forces across the West Bank, and 24 Palestinians, including two children and two women, were injured by Israeli settlers. People known or believed to be Palestinians threw stones at and damaged at least two Israeli-plated vehicles, and the Israeli authorities confiscated one structure in Area C of the West Bank. In the Gaza Strip, in at least 31 incidents, Israeli forces opened “warning fire” near Israel’s perimeter fence or off the coast.

metadata.name: Occupied Palestinian territory: Protection of Civilians Report | 18 April – 1 May 2023

disasters.summary: UNICEF provided access to safe water, treated 27,563 children under 5 for malaria, diarrhea and pneumonia, vaccinated 19,011 children aged 0-59 months against measles, and visited 267 mothers and newborns at home in Titao health district. Additionally, 7,562 new children suffering from severe wasting were treated, including 929 children at community level with simplified approaches.

metadata.name: UNICEF Burkina Faso Humanitarian Situation Report No. 3: March 2023

disasters.summary: Following weeks of tension between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), heavy fighting broke out in Khartoum on 15 April 2023 and extended throughout Sudan. This has exacerbated the already fragile humanitarian situation in the country, with 15.8 million people in need of assistance, including 8.5 million children. At least 550 people have been killed and 4,926 wounded, with over a hundred children killed and nearly two thousand injured. Access to essential supplies is severely constrained, and households are running low on food, fuel and cash. Five aid workers, including four UN staff members, have been killed. Vaccines and cold chain equipment have been destroyed, and access to safe drinking water is a major challenge. Schools and educational institutions are mostly closed, with 7 million school-age children already out of school before the conflict. UNICEF is responding to the crisis by providing humanitarian assistance and advocating for the safety and wellbeing of humanitarian workers and assets.

metadata.name: UNICEF response to Sudan crisis "chapeau": 04 May 2023

disasters.summary: This Global Protection Update provides a country-by-country news update and explores emerging protection trends in the first quarter of 2023. It also focuses on the right of internally displaced persons to participate in elections, highlighting the challenges they face and the measures Protection Clusters are taking to support their enfranchisement.

metadata.name: Global Protection Update (March 2023): Protection During Elections - The Right of Internally Displaced Persons to Participate in Elections

disasters.summary: UNICEF and partners have provided support to 140,286 children in Syria to access formal or non-formal education in a safe and gender sensitive environment. Additionally, UNICEF has provided life-saving WASH services to 765,794 beneficiaries and mental health and psychosocial support services to 12,639 children and caregivers. UNICEF is appealing for US$172.7 million to implement its Immediate Response Plan for the Earthquake, which is 45% funded with US$78.1 million received. UNICEF expresses its gratitude to private and public sector partners for their support and urges all partners to ensure flexible, sustained and predictable resources are provided to the ongoing humanitarian response.

metadata.name: UNICEF Syria Humanitarian Situation Report No. 9 (Earthquake): 12 April - 2 May 2023

disasters.summary: Sudan is currently facing issues with its customs stations, including the Head Quarter, airport, and Suba Dry Port in Khartoum state. The functioning Customs stations are Port Sudan seaports at the Red Sea, Argeen land Crossing at the border with Eygpt, and Galabat land Crossing at the border with Ethiopia. Additionally, two Customs stations in Darfour region have been attacked, destroyed, and looted. The Data Centre for the Asycuda system has not been damaged and the IT team is ready to resume work. The banking system is not functional except for two Bandak applications provided by Khartoum Bank.

metadata.name: Sudan - Importation and Customs Processes, IMPACCT WG, bulletin 1, 5 May 2023

disasters.summary: The Pacific Logistics Cluster (PLC) is working to support the national coordination mechanisms in the Pacific region, which is highly prone to natural disasters due to climate change. In January and March of 2023, the PLC conducted a mission to the Federated States of Micronesia and conducted a Logistics Capacity Assessment in the Republic of the Marshall Islands. In March, Vanuatu declared a State of Emergency due to two cyclones and an earthquake, and the PLC deployed two staff members to support the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) in Port Vila. Two Mobile Storage Units (MSUs) were dispatched to Port Vila to support the NDMO's response efforts.

metadata.name: Pacific: Operation Overview, January - March, 2023

disasters.summary: WHO Regional Director for Europe Dr Hans Henri P. Kluge and WHO Representative (WR) in Ukraine Dr Jarno Habicht visited the WHO Regional Office for Europe in Copenhagen to discuss the impact of war on the health-care system and people’s health in Ukraine. The WHO delegation also visited Odesa, Dnipropetrovsk and Poltava hubs to review the status of the WHO response on the ground. Multiple deaths were reported following Russian forces' strikes across Ukraine. Health care facilities in various regions were damaged or destroyed. The cooperation of the Ministry of Health and the European Commission led to the evacuation of 19 Ukrainians for specialized treatment in clinics in Croatia, and 38 citizens of Ukraine were transported to Poland.

metadata.name: War in Ukraine: Situation report from WHO Ukraine country office. Issue No. 51, 5 May 2023

disasters.summary: UNHCR Romania is providing assistance to 130,387 refugees from Ukraine, including cash assistance, protection counselling services, legal support, livelihoods & employment services, and language courses. On 5 May, the US State Department and Japanese Parliament visited RomExpo to engage with refugees and learn about their needs. UNHCR is also providing a multi-year strategy to cover programmes for refugees from 2024-2026, and organized a training for NGOs and partners on the European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation.

metadata.name: UNHCR Romania: Ukraine Refugee Situation Update, Update #45, 5 May 2023

disasters.summary: Due to insecurity along the Sudan-Central African Republic (CAR) border, traffic has been disrupted and prices of basic commodities have doubled. As a result, 9,700 people, including 3,460 Central African returnees, have fled to Am-Dafock in CAR. Humanitarian actors are prepositioning stocks ahead of the rainy season and providing emergency assistance. The UN Humanitarian Response Plan for CAR is only 22% funded, leaving the capacity to absorb additional needs very limited.

metadata.name: Impact of Sudan crisis in the Central African Republic (Flash Update 5 May 2023)

disasters.summary: The government of Nepal has decided to withdraw the COVID-19 crisis management bill from the federal parliament, while 91 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases in the country to 220.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (May 4, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: Due to five consecutive poor rainy seasons, Somalia is on the edge of famine. UNHCR, with authorities and partners, is delivering life-saving protection assistance to vulnerable IDPs, refugees, asylum seekers, returnees, and vulnerable host communities. UNHCR is also improving inter-agency drought response coordination, providing up-to-date information on internal displacement, piloting a fast-track food referral system, and providing cash assistance for multipurpose use. Other activities include strengthening self-governance systems, employing cash for work schemes, and installing street solar lights.

metadata.name: UNHCR Somalia Drought Response Factsheet (January - April 2023)

disasters.summary: This Health Cluster Bulletin from March 2023 outlines the Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) requirements and progress for the occupied Palestinian territory. A total of 1.1 million people are targeted, with $46.2 million requested in funding. Of those, 1.6 million need assistance, and 380,000 have been reached with $7.1 million received in funding.

metadata.name: occupied Palestinian territory: Health Cluster Bulletin (March 2023)

disasters.summary: This information brief provides an overview of the shelter sector in Turkey, where 720,000 families/2.8 million people are currently living in tents. As summer approaches, additional emergency shelter solutions are needed to cope with the increasing need to service families in tents. Challenges include limited funding and operational capacity to respond to scale, as well as clarity of the available government support packages and services. As of 25/04/2023, 233,264 households have been supported with improved living space and 1,297,432 households have been reached with assistance to resume their domestic life. 42.5% of the 246 million required for the Shelter Sector in the Flash Appeal is funded.

metadata.name: Shelter Sector Türkiye - Information brief Shelter Sector No. 1 - 28/04/2023

disasters.summary: The ETC installed a dedicated solar power system and replaced a faulty antenna in the Damascus Security Operations Centre (SOC) to ensure uninterrupted coverage. Approval was received to conduct a mission to Hama from 7-15 May to install a VHF radio repeater, which will expand radio coverage in rural Hama.

metadata.name: Syria - Conflict ETC Situation Report #59 (Reporting period: 01/03/2023 to 30/04/2023)

disasters.summary: The Syria crisis has been ongoing for 13 years, with 8.8 million people affected by the 6 February earthquakes. UNHCR is transitioning to a longer-term response to address the needs of affected populations, providing core relief items, shelter support, psychosocial support, child protection, and legal assistance. UNHCR is leading the Protection and Shelter/NFI Sectors and working in close coordination with other sectors to effectively assist families affected by the earthquakes in north-west Syria.

metadata.name: Earthquake Emergency Response in The Whole of Syria, Two-Month Progress Report

disasters.summary: This analysis examines the intersection of climate change adaptation and peacebuilding, and how the two can be integrated into National Adaptation Plans (NAPs). It highlights the need for a considered approach to peace, governance and security in order to redefine and raise ambition of adaptation in conflict-affected and fragile contexts. It also discusses the importance of finding connections early on in vulnerability assessments to identify gaps where peacebuilding expertise is needed, and how peacebuilding investments can bolster adaptation results. Finally, it emphasizes the need for environmental peacebuilding to create opportunities for cooperation and build peace.

metadata.name: Re-envisioning Climate Change Adaptation Policy to Sustain Peace - A typology & Analysis of the NAPs

disasters.summary: In March 2023, the World Food Programme (WFP) in The Gambia provided cash-based transfers to 702,177 people and assisted 131,233 people in February and March. WFP is expanding its cash-based transfer and local procurement models in local communities, procuring and transporting food commodities for the prevention and treatment of malnutrition and disaster response/safety net food assistance during the lean season. WFP also received a payout from the African Risk Capacity Limited (ARC Ltd) weather insurance for the failed planting in some regions of The Gambia due to the prolonged dry spell during the 2022 rainy season. The payout was used to provide food assistance to 1,093 households. Additionally, WFP supported the women fish mongers with a “Cooltainer” to preserve fish and reduce losses. A cross-border study tour in Senegal was concluded by WFP Gambia and key stakeholders to learn practical examples from key stakeholders in the micro-insurance sector for a critical understanding of the policies and legal frameworks guiding the delivery of the Weather Index Insurance Mechanisms.

metadata.name: WFP The Gambia Country Brief, March 2023

disasters.summary: Globally, there has been a decrease in reported cases and deaths of 17% and 30%, respectively, compared to the previous 28 days. However, there are increases in reported cases and deaths in the South-East Asia, Eastern Mediterranean, and Western Pacific regions. As of 30 April 2023, over 765 million confirmed cases and over 6.9 million deaths have been reported globally. The highest numbers of new 28-day cases were reported from the United States of America, the Republic of Korea, Japan, India, and France. The highest numbers of new 28-day deaths were reported from the United States of America, Brazil, the Russian Federation, France, and the Islamic Republic of Iran.

metadata.name: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19): Weekly Epidemiological Update (4 May 2023)

disasters.summary: This dashboard provides an overview of the child rights and humanitarian situation in the Sahel region in December 2022.

metadata.name: Sahel: Child Rights and Humanitarian Dashboard - December 2022

disasters.summary: This UNICEF Türkiye Humanitarian Situation Report No. 10 covers the period of 18-25 April 2023, following an earthquake. It highlights that 2.4 million people are living in formal sites and informal settlements, with key needs being access to adequate water and sanitation, information on available services and social protection schemes. To date, 1,914 unaccompanied children have been identified, of whom 1,880 have been reunified with their families or are in long-term alternative care. UNICEF has cumulatively reached 212,730 children and caregivers with mental health and psychosocial support and psychological first aid. The first 200,000 doses of Measles, Mumps and Rubella vaccine have been delivered to the Ministry of Health, and UNICEF is leading the WASH sector group, having cumulatively reached 2.41 million people with WASH assistance. There is a funding gap of over US$ 87 million (44%) against a funding requirement of US$ 196 million to reach 3 million people, including 1.5 million children.

metadata.name: UNICEF Türkiye Humanitarian Situation Report No. 10 (Earthquake), 18-25 April 2023

disasters.summary: Torrential rains, floods and landslides have severely affected northern and central Peruvian coastal departments, resulting in a dire humanitarian situation. Official figures indicate that 522,200 people are in need of assistance, with almost 30,000 homes destroyed or rendered uninhabitable. The National Civil Defence Institute (INDECI) has assisted 67,882 people as of 30 April, and the National Humanitarian Network's (RHN) Shelter sector estimates that there are 2,757 people in shelters and spontaneous settlements. The United States' National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Climate Prediction Center forecasts that the next few weeks could see an increase in the likelihood of heavy rains for northern Peru. The main needs remain food, access to safe water, sanitation, health services, protection and livelihoods.

metadata.name: Peru: Flooding - Situation Report No. 05 (as of 3 May 2023)

disasters.summary: This issue of the Humanitarian Update for the Syrian Arab Republic highlights the ongoing assistance provided by the UN to those affected by earthquakes and floods in the region. It also outlines the dire socio-economic conditions and internal displacement caused by the earthquakes, as well as the impact of the Aleppo International Airport strikes and the low level of the Euphrates river and rainfall on farmers. Additionally, it discusses the population movements and the impact of deforestation in Syria.

metadata.name: Humanitarian Update Syrian Arab Republic - Issue 10 | March 2023

disasters.summary: On February 13, 2023, the Minister of Health and Social Welfare of Equatorial Guinea declared an outbreak of Marburg Virus Disease (MVD). Since then, 17 cases have been confirmed, including 12 deaths, 4 survivors, and one unknown. 5 health workers have also been confirmed cases. As of April 30, 2023, there have been no active cases since April 26. UNICEF, in collaboration with the Government of Equatorial Guinea, WHO, and other partners have continued implementing the response plan. 4 provinces have been affected.

metadata.name: UNICEF Equatorial Guinea: Marburg Virus Disease - MVD Situation Report #2 - Period Covered: 1-30 April 2023

disasters.summary: The ETC was activated in the Central African Republic in December 2013 in response to the conflict crisis. During the reporting period of April 1-30, the WFP TEC Chief Information Officer and Regional IT Officer visited the Learning Centre and Cyber Café in Bangassou, and the first batch of 60 learners completed the computer training course and were issued certificates. Additionally, a new configuration in the customer management software platform was finalized to enable the establishment of the Common Feedback Mechanism in Bangassou and Bouar.

metadata.name: Central African Republic Conflict - ETC Situation Report #63 (Reporting period: 01/04/2023 to 30/04/2023)

disasters.summary: UNHCR has donated 23 mobile coordination centers to AFAD in response to the Syria crisis in 20-3. One of these centers is currently stationed in Malatya, Turkey, to provide information and services to the earthquake-affected population, such as verifying documents and information on damaged buildings, complaints, cash assistance, registration for tents, and coordination.

metadata.name: UNHCR Türkiye Earthquake Emergency Response (04 May 2023)

disasters.summary: The Global Report on Food Crises 2023, published by the Food Security Information Network (FSIN) in support of the Global Network against Food Crises (GNAFC), highlights that the number of people experiencing high levels of acute food insecurity and requiring urgent food and livelihood assistance increased for the fourth consecutive year in 2022. The report is the result of a collaborative effort among 16 partners and aims to inform humanitarian and development action by independent and consensus-based evidence and analysis.

metadata.name: Global Report on Food Crises 2023

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 55 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 252. President Ramchandra Paudel has expressed his desire to cover medical expenses incurred during his treatment in India. Additionally, the consultation fee of doctors is set to increase by 14 percent, effective from May 15.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (May 3, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: Clashes between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have been ongoing for 17 days, prompting the UN High Commissioner for Refugees to prepare for the possibility of over 800,000 people fleeing the fighting. UNHCR and partners are scaling up relief efforts as cross-border movements from Sudan increase, with an estimated 100,000 refugee and refugee returnee arrivals already. The World Food Programme has lifted the temporary suspension of operations in Sudan, and the Civil Aviation Authority has announced that Sudan’s airspace will remain closed until 13 May with the exception of aid and evacuation flights. The UN Secretary-General has appointed Clementine Nkweta-Salami of Cameroon as his Deputy Special Representative for Sudan with the United Nations Integrated Transition Assistance Mission in Sudan (UNITAMS). The UN Emergency Relief Coordinator and Under Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs, Martin Griffiths, has been sent to the region.

metadata.name: Sudan Situation - UNHCR External Update #4 - 2 May 2023

disasters.summary: During the first quarter of 2023, Israeli authorities demolished, forced people to demolish or seized 290 Palestinian-owned structures across the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, resulting in the displacement of 413 people, including 194 children. 43 of the targeted structures were provided as humanitarian aid, and two donor-funded schools became at increased risk of imminent demolition. Additionally, six Palestinian-owned homes and one agricultural-related structure were demolished or sealed by the Israeli authorities on punitive grounds. These demolitions are a form of collective punishment, prohibited under international law.

metadata.name: West Bank demolitions and displacement: An overview | January - March 2023

disasters.summary: In April, the ETC provided data connectivity services to 1,298 humanitarians and security communications services to 2,396 responders across 20 sites in Yemen. Additionally, a telecommunications specialist sponsored by the ETC arrived in Aden to provide training to UNDSS Security Operations Centre Operators in Aden, Marib, and Al Mokha. The ETC also set up dedicated bandwidth and Wi-Fi connectivity for the UN Mission to support the Hodeidah Agreement in Al-Mokha.

metadata.name: Yemen Conflict - ETC Situation Report #79 (Reporting period: 01/04/2023 to 30/04/2023)

disasters.summary: The conflict between the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) has been ongoing for two weeks, resulting in civilian deaths, destruction of infrastructure, and displacement of over 334,000 people. IOM is calling on all parties to cease hostilities and allow unrestricted access to humanitarian aid. IOM is also appealing for the restoration of calm and dialogue to resolve the crisis. The population is struggling to cope with depleting access to health care, water, and food, and rising prices of goods and services. IOM is working on a response plan and appeal to enable the scale up needed to respond in Sudan and neighboring countries.

metadata.name: Sudan: Escalating Conflict Situation Update 01 May 2023

disasters.summary: Heavy fighting continues in Ukraine, resulting in 18,657 civilian casualties since February of last year. The conflict has eroded access to health care services and medicines, particularly for those living in regions closer to the front line. 17.6 million people are in need of humanitarian aid, with 14.6 million in need of health assistance. 7.8 million of the most vulnerable people in Ukraine will be targeted by the health humanitarian response.

metadata.name: Ukraine: Health Cluster Bulletin #1 (January - February 2023) [EN/UK]

disasters.summary: The IOM has scaled up its drought response significantly in Somalia and Ethiopia since January 2022, reaching more than 3.5 million people. Despite a good start to the March to June 2023 rainy season, the overall performance remains unclear and the humanitarian situation remains dire. IOM has provided assistance to almost 1.9 million people in March, including health assistance, Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM), WASH assistance, and shelter/Non-Food Item (NFI) assistance.

metadata.name: IOM East and Horn of Africa Drought Response - Situation Report (1 - 31 March 2023)

disasters.summary: IOM Libya's Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) recorded the arrival of close to 700 individuals - both Sudanese and third-country nationals - in Alkufra (Libya) from Sudan and via Chad between 15 April and 2 May 2023, following the onset of armed clashes in Sudan in mid-April.

metadata.name: IOM Libya Emergency Tracking - Sudan Situation: Update 1 (3 May 2023)

disasters.summary: The SCALA programme recognizes the important role of the private sector in driving innovation and investment for climate action in the agrifood sector. This guidance note outlines three intervention areas to address barriers to private sector engagement in climate action, such as misalignment of public and private sector objectives, limited understanding of climate risks and business opportunities, and lack of investable ideas with adequate scale and risk-adjusted returns.

metadata.name: Private sector mapping, outreach, and engagement in climate-responsive agrifood systems

disasters.summary: This report examines the need for a comprehensive risk-management approach to address the complex interplay of natural hazards, climate change, pandemic threats, violence and conflict, food insecurity, and economic fluctuations. It highlights the importance of Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) in bridging the humanitarian-development-peace (HDP) nexus, and calls for further exploration of the potential for DRR to contribute to conflict prevention and peacebuilding.

metadata.name: Evidence of positive progress on disaster risk reduction in the humanitarian-development-peace nexus: Thematic report to inform the Midterm Review of the Sendai Framework

disasters.summary: The World Food Programme (WFP) Democratic Republic of the Congo March Situation Report #46 highlights the increasing insecurity, rising prices, and the appointment of a new Executive Director, Cindy McCain. Insecurity has caused catastrophic conditions for displaced populations, with food, medicines and nutritional inputs lacking and malnutrition increasing. Prices of a food basket have increased by 77 percent in Goma and 100 percent in Bukavu since the year prior. The new Executive Director, Cindy McCain, was previously the Permanent Representative of the United States to the United Nations agencies in Rome.

metadata.name: WFP Democratic Republic of the Congo March Situation Report #46 - 2 May 2023

disasters.summary: WHO has released an updated two-year COVID-19 Global Strategic Preparedness, Readiness and Response Plan (SPRP) 2023-2025 to guide countries in transitioning from an emergency phase to a longer-term, sustained response. The plan focuses on sustaining gains made during the pandemic, such as surveillance, and preventing, controlling, and managing the virus. The International Health Regulations Emergency Committee on COVID-19 will meet to advise the WHO Director-General on whether the pandemic is still a public health emergency of international concern.

metadata.name: Strategic preparedness and response plan: April 2023–April 2025 - From emergency response to long-term COVID-19 disease management: Sustaining gains made during the COVID-19 pandemic, 3 May 2023

disasters.summary: A grave humanitarian crisis is unfolding in the area surrounding Marinka, in Donetska oblast, where approximately 5,000 civilians are enduring heavy ground fighting and hostilities. This has also affected the neighbouring Kurakhove and Vuhledar communities, home to another 24,000 civilians, due to the direct impact of the hostilities and the pressure over the limited services and resources. Widespread destruction has decimated access to food, water, electricity, gas, health care and other essential services, forcing people to rely heavily on humanitarian aid and the support from volunteer groups to survive. Humanitarians are striving to complement the assistance provided by authorities and volunteer groups, despite immense challenges imposed by the security situation.

metadata.name: Ukraine: Deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Donetska oblast - Flash Update #3: Marinka, Vuhledar and Kurakhove (3 May 2023) [EN/RU/UK]

disasters.summary: In February 2023, WFP provided cash-based transfers to 9,000 beneficiaries (53% women and girls) in five departments, nutritional assessments and micronutrient supplementation to 4,000 beneficiaries (71% children under 5), asset creation activities to 2,300 beneficiaries (90% women) in four departments, and training on pedagogical school gardens, nutrition, financial literacy, and the use of the School Feeding Mobile Application to 400 beneficiaries (85% women) in five departments. Additionally, WFP launched a pilot project to assist 1,000 beneficiaries in Guatemala City and Villa Nueva, and planned to complement the CBT assistance by providing capacity strengthening activities to promote employment opportunities for youth in urban areas.

metadata.name: WFP Guatemala Country Brief, February 2023

disasters.summary: In April 2022, UNHCR and IOM urged for increased international support for refugees and migrants from Venezuela and the communities in Latin America and the Caribbean that host them. The U.N. Secretary General called for the deployment of an international specialized armed force to Haiti and for governments to consider halting deportations. The Law for the Prevention, Protection, and Assistance of Internally Displaced Persons in Honduras was sanctioned and will come into force on 19 April. UNHCR expressed serious concern by the arbitrary deprivation of the Nicaraguan nationality of over 300 people. In Panama, over 87,000 people entered irregularly through Darién from January to March 2023. Due to the militarization of the border between Chile and Peru, UNHCR and partners have deployed efforts to provide basic needs to displaced populations.

metadata.name: UNHCR Americas Operational Update, April 2022

disasters.summary: As of 3 May 2023, over 11,000 people have crossed into Ethiopia due to the ongoing situation in Sudan. Partners are providing basic humanitarian aid including emergency health services, drinking water, sleeping mats, high energy biscuits, and transportation. Primary needs include food, drinking water and latrines, emergency shelter, and adequate health and protection services. An Incident Command Post (ICP) has been established in West Gondar to provide collective humanitarian relief to returning Ethiopians, refugees, and other nationalities.

metadata.name: Flash Update #1: The Impact of the Situation in Sudan on Ethiopia (As of 3 May 2023)

disasters.summary: The Emergency Telecommunications Sector (ETS) conducted a demonstration of the CrisisNet quick deployment kit to the World Food Programme (WFP) CIO during a visit to an IDP camp in Bama, Nigeria. The ETS also provided data connectivity to 70 tablet devices used by an NGO for a data collection survey across Borno state. Additionally, the ETS is installing a telecommunications tower in Yola to improve radio network signal coverage.

metadata.name: Nigeria - Conflict: ETS Situation Report #78 (Reporting period: 01/04/2023 to 30/04/2023)

disasters.summary: In 2023, the humanitarian community in the Central African Republic (CAR) plans to assist 2.4 million of the most vulnerable people, requiring US$ 465 million. In 2022, 1.9 million people were provided with life-saving assistance, representing 93% of the Humanitarian Response Plan target. CAR has one of the highest proportions of critically food-insecure people in the world, and humanitarian and development actors are helping internally displaced persons and refugees to resume a normal life. The 2023 Humanitarian Response Plan aims to provide multi-sectoral assistance to those in need, with a focus on localization, accountability, and the nexus between emergency response and assistance.

metadata.name: Central African Republic: Situation Report, 2 May 2023

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 19 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 283. Outpatient (OPD) charges in hospitals are set to increase from 15th May, and President Ramchandra Paudel has returned home after his treatment on Sunday night.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (May 2, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: In December 2022, conflict in Jonglei state escalated and displaced an estimated 20,000 people to Malakal town, Canal/Pigi, Baliet, and Ulang counties. Gokjak, a spontaneous site in Mareng Payam (Piji/Canal County, Jonglei state), is home to 2,123 households (roughly 16,884 individuals). The majority of the population are women, children, elderly and persons living with disabilities. The local authorities have given the IDPs the area to construct shelters and cultivate, but they lack the tools to do so. There are three policemen present to ensure security, law, and order.

metadata.name: Protection Cluster Upper Nile/Jonglei - Internal displacement in Gokjak, Piji/Canal county (April 2023)

disasters.summary: In April, a small outbreak of Desert Locusts developed on the Red Sea coast of Saudi Arabia, with late instar hopper groups, bands, and new immature adult groups present. Control operations were carried out. In Northwest Africa, small hopper groups and bands occurred south of the Atlas Mountains in Morocco and Western Sahara. Low numbers of adults were present in Yemen, southeast Egypt, northwest Somalia, and southwest Pakistan. Weather models suggest that the summer season rains may start in the Sahel during June this year, and small-scale breeding may occur in Yemen, southeast Iran, and southwest Pakistan.

metadata.name: Desert Locust Bulletin 535 (2 May 2023)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, over 4,000 people were displaced in the Far North region of Cameroon due to violence and insecurity caused by non-State armed groups. Floods and mudslides from Mount Cameroon affected over 3,000 people in the South-West, and 54% of schools remain closed in the North-West and South-West. UNHCR facilitated the voluntary repatriation of 200 refugees from the Central African Republic (CAR). The Cameroonian-based NGO Reach Out participated in the 67th Commission of the Status of Women. Humanitarian partners have scaled up urgent response activities such as shelter, food, health, nutrition, education, water, hygiene, and sanitation, but numerous needs remain uncovered.

metadata.name: Cameroon Humanitarian Bulletin March 2023

disasters.summary: The United Nations Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process has issued a report for the upcoming Ad Hoc Liaison Committee meeting in Brussels, calling for a strategic shift by Israeli and Palestinian leaders, and the international community to reverse the current unsustainable trajectory that is eroding Palestinian institutional, economic, and development gains. The report identifies necessary immediate steps to address challenges, and reiterates the urgency of a strategic shift in approach by the parties and the international community. It calls for a coherent package of steps to reverse negative trends and conflict drivers, strengthen the Palestinian Authority and open space for the Palestinian economy to grow, alongside and as an integral part of efforts to restore a political horizon toward achieving the vision of two States.

metadata.name: Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process - Report to the Ad Hoc Liaison Committee, 3 May 2023

disasters.summary: The conflict between Sudan and the Central African Republic (CAR) has caused a disruption in traffic between the two countries, resulting in a sharp increase in the price of basic commodities. This has exacerbated the already severe food insecurity in northern CAR, with an estimated 120,000 people in need of humanitarian assistance and protection. Humanitarian teams have arrived in Am-Dafock from Birao to provide emergency assistance, including clean water and emergency shelters. International Medical Corps (IMC) is providing medical, nutritional and mental health response to the most vulnerable. The 2023 Humanitarian Response Plan is only 22% funded, and the capacity to absorb additional needs is very limited.

metadata.name: Impact of Sudan crisis in the Central African Republic (Flash Update 2 May 2023)

disasters.summary: This report provides key lessons and areas of good practice for designing inclusive and accessible early warning systems (EWS). It is aimed at development practitioners, especially World Bank staff, and provides evidence-based approaches to enhance inclusion of different social groups in EWS. The report outlines characteristics of inclusive, accessible EWS, such as being long-term social processes, using multiple channels, modes, and messages, being relevant to everyone, connecting all governance levels, and extending beyond warning dissemination. It also recommends early and anticipatory action to reduce inequalities and inequities.

metadata.name: Designing Inclusive, Accessible Early Warning Systems: Good Practices and Entry Points

disasters.summary: The ETC in the Pacific was activated in 2016 to support telecommunications preparedness in the region. From 15 January 2022 to 4 April 2023, the ETC provided emergency response support to Tonga following the eruption of the Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Ha’apai underwater volcano and subsequent tsunami. This included providing nine prepaid satellite phones, three portable BGAN satellite terminals, and two sets of emergency.lu VSAT satellite terminals. The ETC also collaborated with the Government of Tonga to install HF radio systems on the islands of ‘Eua, Vava'u, and Ha’apai. As of 4 April 2023, the ETC has transitioned service delivery and coordination through a handover to the Tongan Ministry of Meteorology, Energy, Information, Disaster Management, Environment, Climate Change and Communications (MEIDECC) and the National Emergency Management Office (NEMO).

metadata.name: Tonga: Hunga Tonga - Hunga Ha'apai Volcano [FINAL] ETC Situation Report #18 Reporting period: 15/01/2022 to 30/04/2023

disasters.summary: The World Food Programme (WFP) led ETC in the Pacific was activated in 2016 to support telecommunications preparedness in the region. In response to Tropical Cyclones Judy and Kevin which hit Vanuatu on 1 and 3 March 2023, the ETC deployed an officer to assess communications and connectivity needs, provided push-to-talk (PTT) satellite phones and a Broadband Global Area Network (BGAN) terminal, and installed a Starlink satellite data terminal at the Penama Provincial Emergency Operations Centre (PEOC) and Tafea PEOC. These services enabled users to communicate with the National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) at the NDMO headquarters in Port Vila.

metadata.name: Vanuatu - earthquake and cyclones emergency [FINAL] ETC Situation Report #7 (Reporting period: 03/03/2023 to 22/04/2023)

disasters.summary: Indonesia's Country Climate and Development Report (CCDR) takes a historical look at climate and development challenges in the country to create a framework to illustrate climate-growth dynamics. Indonesia has made commitments to meet its climate and development targets, and is looking for ways to maintain economic and social growth with low GHG emissions. The CCDR does not take a position on Indonesia's climate commitments, but aims to assess how the country can achieve its climate goals while maximizing its development outcomes.

metadata.name: Indonesia: Country Climate and Development Report (April 2023)

disasters.summary: In April 2023, thousands of people have fled from Sudan into Chad due to conflict, and the Humanitarian Response Plan requires USD 674.1 million to reach 4.4 million people in need of assistance. The plan has three strategic objectives to strengthen the emergency response, reduce the impact of shocks, and establish a framework for linking humanitarian assistance with development programmes. In addition, the national authorities have announced their intention to close the sites for displaced persons in N'Djamena following the 2022 floods, and the Humanitarian Country Team (HCT) has developed a strategy to launch innovative initiatives to mobilise the necessary financial resources.

metadata.name: Chad Humanitarian Update April 2023

disasters.summary: During the January-February 2023 period, the UN Country Team mission to Aruba identified potential areas for collaboration with the government and people of Aruba to support the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In Curaçao, a delegation from the Venezuelan government visited to discuss re-opening the borders, and in the Dominican Republic, 23,725 visas had been issued for Venezuelans in the Normalization Plan for Venezuelans (PNV). In Guyana, funds were allocated to improve indigenous education, and in Trinidad and Tobago, the Administration of Justice (Indictable Proceedings) Amendment Act fast-tracked prosecutions for certain sexual and human trafficking offenses. US Ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago Candace Bond also promised to collaborate with Trinidad and Tobago on human trafficking and the welfare of Venezuelan refugees and migrants.

metadata.name: Caribbean Situation Report January - February 2023

disasters.summary: The World Bank's Pakistan Human Capital Review report highlights the need for Pakistan to increase investments in human capital to address the severe gaps in education and health outcomes. The report documents and quantifies the country's human capital crisis, with a Human Capital Index of 0.41, and outlines recommendations for Pakistan to boost its human capital, such as long-term planning, investing in people, and reducing out-of-school children.

metadata.name: Pakistan – Human Capital Review: Building Capabilities Throughout Life

disasters.summary: South Asia has the highest number of child brides in the world, accounting for 45% of the global total. Despite progress in reducing child marriage in recent decades, the combined impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, economic shocks, conflict and climate change threatens to erode these gains. Acceleration is needed to meet the global SDG target of eliminating child marriage by 2030.

metadata.name: A Profile of Child Marriage in South Asia

disasters.summary: India has made progress in reducing the rate of child marriage, but it still has the highest number of child brides in the world. The prevalence of child marriage varies across states and union territories, and girls from rural areas and poorer households are more likely to be married before 18. Fewer than 2 in 10 married girls remain in school, and progress has been accelerating over the last 15 years. India is making progress compared to other countries in South Asia, but additional efforts are needed to reach the goal of eliminating child marriage by 2030.

metadata.name: Ending Child Marriage: A profile of progress in India (2023 update)

disasters.summary: UNICEF is responding to the influx of 30,000 people to Chad, with a projected influx of 100,000 by the end of the month. UNHCR and CNARR are leading the response, with UNICEF providing NFI kits, water, medical supplies, and protection services. UNICEF has also signed an agreement with the CRT to provide communication activities and complaint and feedback mechanisms.

metadata.name: UNICEF Chad Humanitarian Flash Update No. 3: 02 May 2023

disasters.summary: This weekly report covers the rainfall, water levels, and drought conditions in the Lower Mekong River Basin from April 25-May 1, 2023. Rainfall was observed in some areas, while water levels were mostly below their long-term average value. Drought conditions were observed in some areas in the middle part of the basin. The forecast for the next 7 days is for warm temperatures and below average rainfall, with water levels expected to remain lower than their long-term average value. June is forecasted to be normal with average rainfall, and July is expected to be wet, except for slightly below average rainfall in southern Cambodia.

metadata.name: Weekly Dry Season Situation Report in the Lower Mekong River Basin - 25 April-01 May 2023

disasters.summary: The Emergency Telecommunications Sector (ETS) is co-led by WFP and the Government of Türkiye Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure to support the response in the areas affected by the multiple earthquakes that struck on 6 February 2023. During this reporting period, the ETS continued to participate in support and planning activities across five affected areas. There are 20 charging station units established in two temporary settlements in the affected areas of Türkiye. The ETS is also procuring security communications equipment to upgrade existing UHF radio repeater sites and add two more UHF radio sites. The response to the earthquakes is led by the Government of Türkiye, with the international humanitarian community providing assistance. People displaced after the earthquakes are showing interest in returning to their areas of origin, however a heavy storm hit Pazarcık district in Kahramanmaraş on 20 April, damaging tents and containers in both informal and formal settlements.

metadata.name: Türkiye - Earthquake response - ETS Situation Report #10 (Reporting period: 18/04/2023 to 01/05/2023)

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 60 new coronavirus cases have been reported in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 328.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (May 1, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: The Islamic Republic of Iran has been providing asylum to refugees for over four decades and is currently host to one of the largest and most protracted urban refugee situations in the world. In March, UNHCR launched the 2023 Afghanistan Situation Regional Refugee Response Plan (RRP) to support host governments and ensure the needs of Afghans and their host communities can be met. Iranian borders remain closed, but Afghans continue to make their way to Iran informally. Over 1,000,000 Afghans have fled to Iran since January 2021, and sustained international humanitarian support is needed to help the Government of Iran maintain its inclusive refugee policies.

metadata.name: UNHCR Iran Factsheet, January-March 2023

disasters.summary: The Syria crisis has been ongoing for 13 years, with 15.3 million people in need of humanitarian assistance. The 6 February earthquakes have further exacerbated the situation, with 8.8 million people affected. UNHCR is responding to the new emergency and providing protection and assistance to refugees, asylum-seekers, internally displaced people, returnees, stateless people, and host community members.

metadata.name: Syria: UNHCR Operational Update, March 2023

disasters.summary: UNRWA has been visiting families affected by the earthquakes in Aleppo city and Neirab Camp to assess their situation. 1,076 Palestine refugee homes have been identified as damaged, with 11 UNRWA installations also affected. UNRWA is in need of urgent funding to repair and rehabilitate refugee shelters and installations, as well as providing cash assistance, education, health, mental health and psychosocial support services. A brief household level survey was conducted in March 2023 to assess the most critical needs, the findings of which are summarised in Annex 1.

metadata.name: UNRWA Syria earthquake response Situation report #25 - 27 April 2023

disasters.summary: UNHCR has resumed counselling and psychosocial services for refugees and asylum-seekers in five legal clinics in Gaziantep, Kilis, Malatya, Hatay and Sanllurfa. The Hatay legal clinic, which was destroyed during the earthquake, has resumed services online, and options are being assessed to install containers for in-person counselling in Hatay and Malatya.

metadata.name: UNHCR Türkiye Earthquake Emergency Response (28 April 2023)

disasters.summary: As of February 2023, 8.1 million refugees from Ukraine were recorded across Europe, while 4.9 million registered for Temporary Protection or similar national protection schemes. Within Ukraine, 5.4 million people were internally displaced. UNHCR published its third report of intentions surveys with refugees from Ukraine, as well as the first report of surveys with IDPs within Ukraine. The majority of refugees and IDPs want to return home one day, however, only 12% of both refugees and IDPs plan to do so in the next three months. Factors influencing their decisions include access to basic services and rights in host countries, socio-demographic characteristics, and an end to the war and related safety risks.

metadata.name: UNHCR Europe situations: Data and trends - Arrivals and displaced populations (February 2023)

disasters.summary: This market situation update for Tajikistan covers the period of April 24-30, 2023. Prices for basic commodities such as wheat flour, vegetable and cottonseed oils decreased, while the average price of sugar, beef, and eggs increased. Prices for vegetables decreased due to the beginning of the harvest season, while prices for carrots and potatoes increased. Prices for petrol and diesel remained the same, while LPG prices decreased by 1%.

metadata.name: Tajikistan Market Situation Update, No. 17 (April 24 - April 30, 2023)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, WFP provided USD 0.9 million in cash-based transfers to 15,214 people, including Venezuelan migrants and local communities. WFP also launched an emergency operation in four regions affected by torrential rains, assisting 7,177 beneficiaries with USD 170 to cover 50 percent of the monthly basic food basket cost. Additionally, WFP provided humanitarian logistics services to transport 916 mt of food and non-food items to 262,688 people affected by landslides, and transported 406 mt of unsold food to 13 districts in Lima.

metadata.name: WFP Peru Country Brief, March 2023

disasters.summary: As of April 2023, 129,438 refugees from Ukraine have been granted temporary protection in Romania, with 101,341 refugees currently in the country. The Romanian government has established a programme to provide refugees with monthly cash assistance to cover accommodation and food expenses, with exemptions for elderly people, persons with disabilities, and care givers of children. UNHCR is providing additional assistance to 35,000 refugees, as well as career coaching, language classes, and trainings. They are also raising awareness of the new programme and providing protection services and legal support to 28,348 refugees. In addition, UNHCR has distributed 190,000 core-relief items to refugees in Romania.

metadata.name: UNHCR Romania: Ukraine Refugee Situation Update, Update #44, 28 April 2023

disasters.summary: WFP is providing food assistance to refugees who have fled the crisis in Sudan, and has reprioritized 340 MT of food for the Farchana area. Prepositioning of food for 100,000 Sudanese refugees and host communities is urgently needed before the start of the rainy season in June. WFP plans to provide 2 months of in-kind food and 4 months of cash-based transfers. The situation in Chad’s border area of Adre is compounded by food scarcity and WFP has observed a 54% rise in the price of sorghum.

metadata.name: WFP Chad Emergency Action in Support of the Government’s Response: External Situation Report #1 - April 2023

disasters.summary: The ongoing conflict in Sudan is having a severe impact on the Central African Republic (CAR), particularly in the northern region. Prices of basic commodities have doubled, and the region is already experiencing acute food insecurity. Approximately 6,000 people, including 400 Central African returnees, have crossed the border from Sudan and are living in spontaneous settlements in Am-Dafock, CAR. The most pressing needs include emergency shelter, food, clean water, and latrines. Humanitarian teams are providing emergency assistance and the humanitarian community is working hard to ensure those in need receive required assistance in a timely manner.

metadata.name: Impact of Sudan crisis in the Central African Republic (Flash Update 30 Apr 2023)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, WFP provided food assistance to 1,272,575 earthquake-affected people in Turkey. This included cash assistance to 60,306 people, 53,760 food packages to 268,800 people, and e-vouchers to 13,024 people. WFP also provided seven mobile kitchens to municipalities and governorates in Adıyaman, Hatay and Kahramanmaraş. WFP's six-month net funding requirements for April-September 2023 are US$ 62.2 million.

metadata.name: WFP Türkiye Country Brief, March 2023

disasters.summary: The Shelter Cluster Afghanistan Regional Monthly Update for March 2023 reported that ESNFI clusters partners have provided emergency shelters and NFI assistance to 242,845 individuals since the beginning of the year. On 21 March, a magnitude 6.5 earthquake struck Badakhshan Province, affecting 259 people. Additionally, heavy rainfall incidents have affected 177 families in several provinces across Afghanistan.

metadata.name: Shelter Cluster Afghanistan: Regional Monthly Update 01 - 31 March 2023

disasters.summary: As of March 31, 2021, 210,576 confirmed cases and 7,883 deaths of COVID-19 have been reported in Afghanistan, with a 91.5% recovery rate and 3.7% case fatality rate. Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI) and Acute Diarrheal Disease (ADD) are the leading causes of morbidity among all age groups. WHO has distributed 636 different types of emergency medical kits to benefit 112,100 people in 34 provinces over the next three months. UNFPA and its partners have delivered RMNCAH services through 114 Mobile Health and Nutrition Teams, 8 Basic Health Centers, 3 Zero Point Health Facilities, and 1 Transition Center in 24 provinces. INTERSOS is present in three provinces providing integrated health, nutrition, and protection services. OCCD has supported health, nutrition, and trauma care services in 16 provinces through 50 fixed health facilities, 34 MHNTs, and two first aid trauma centers.

metadata.name: Afghanistan Health Cluster Bulletin, March 2023

disasters.summary: In April 2023, the World Food Programme (WFP) reached 9.2 million people in Afghanistan with emergency food, nutrition, and livelihood assistance. However, due to severe funding constraints, 8 million people have been cut from emergency food assistance since April. Nearly 20 million people are projected to be acutely food-insecure between November 2022 and March 2023, including more than 6 million people in Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) Phase 4 (Emergency). Additionally, 4 million people are acutely malnourished, including 3.2 million children under 5. The economic crisis, compounded by decades of conflict, climate shocks, and severe restrictions on the rights of women and girls to work and pursue higher education, has caused the highest risk of famine in a quarter of a century.

metadata.name: WFP Afghanistan: Situation Report, 30 April 2023

disasters.summary: In the first quarter of 2023, below-average rainfall and rising production and transport costs have caused a reduced availability of produce for domestic consumption and export, resulting in high wholesale prices of maize and beans. Food insecurity in the Arid and Semi-Arid Lands (ASALs) of Kenya, southern Ethiopia, and Somalia has been exacerbated by the drought. Cereal prices across all WFP monitored markets in Burundi, Ethiopia, Rwanda, Sudan, and South Sudan increased by more than 50 percent compared to the five-year average. Beans prices have almost tripled in Burundi and almost doubled in South Sudan. Local currencies across Eastern Africa have lost their value against the U.S. dollar, and fuel prices have remained high. The cost of living and food inflation have also been significantly higher than one year ago, with the average per capita monthly price of a local food basket reaching USD 18.2 across the Region.

metadata.name: WFP Regional Bureau for Eastern Africa: Market and Trade Update – 2023 Q1 Joint Procurement and RAM (April 2023)

disasters.summary: The Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC) was activated in Ukraine in March 2022 due to the armed conflict between Ukraine and the Russian Federation. During the reporting period of April 2023, the ETC finalized a service agreement with the Ukraine Broadcast and Radio Telecommunications Concern (BRT) to expand the VHF radio network in five cities, started working on a Remote Site on Vehicle (RSoV) project, and conducted a survey to propose time slots for security communications training sessions. The conflict has led to 5.4 million internally displaced people and 8.2 million refugees, and has caused severe damage to national telecommunications infrastructure. The ETC is exploring solutions to provide responders with services and equipment.

metadata.name: Ukraine ETC Situation Report #22 (Reporting period: 01/04/2023 to 30/04/2023)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, Vanuatu experienced two cyclones, causing significant damage to infrastructure and affecting almost half of the population. UNICEF has provided critical supplies to at least 9,000 people in the most affected areas and is actively assisting the government in coordinating, assessing, and responding to the impacts of the cyclones across various crucial sectors, including WASH, Health, Nutrition, Education, Protection and Social Policy. The government of Vanuatu launched an early recovery plan on April 14th, with a budget of USD 28,000,000, and UNICEF is providing technical assistance for the Post Disaster Needs Assessment (PDNA). UNICEF is also supporting the roll out of Humanitarian Cash Transfers (HCT) in collaboration with other civil society organizations.

metadata.name: UNICEF Vanuatu Humanitarian Situation Report No. 6 (Tropical Cyclones) - 28 March - 25 April 2023

disasters.summary: This report covers the period until 28 April 2023 and provides an overview of the situation in Mozambique following the triple crisis of Cyclone Freddy, floods, and cholera. Over 1 million people have been affected, with 385,930 people receiving some form of assistance and 197,000 people receiving direct humanitarian assistance. The Cholera, Cyclone and Floods Response Plan was launched to support 815,000 people affected by the triple crisis, with a financial requirement of U$138 million. Urgent contributions are sought to support people affected by cholera, Cyclone and Floods.

metadata.name: Mozambique: Tropical Cyclone Freddy, Floods and Cholera - Situation Report No.3

disasters.summary: In Honduras, 247,000 people have been internally displaced due to violence between 2004 and 2018. From 2015 to March 2023, 572,000 Honduran nationals have been returned. In the first trimester of 2023, 60,532 persons of different nationalities entered Honduras irregularly. UNHCR and its partners have provided services such as shelter, cash and voucher assistance, community protection, case management and risk mitigation to 15,225 mainly internally displaced persons, but also asylum-seekers, returnees, mixed movements, and host community members so far in 2023.

metadata.name: Honduras Operational Update 17 - April 2023

disasters.summary: This report covers the humanitarian situation and response to the earthquakes in Türkiye from 21 to 27 April 2023. 9.1 million people have been affected, with 5.2 million targeted for humanitarian assistance, 3 million people having to relocate from their homes, and 1.6 million people staying in informal settlements. 50,000 people have been killed and 107,000 people injured. A major storm affected 300 households in Pazarcık, injuring about 45 people and damaging shelter and possessions. Partners plan to increase cash and voucher assistance in several sectors to address an evolution in needs and conditions. The Flash Appeal for US$1 billion to assist 5.2 million people affected by the earthquakes is 30.2 per cent funded. The response to the earthquakes is being led by the Government of Türkiye in coordination with AFAD and with support from the Turkish Red Crescent (TRC).

metadata.name: Türkiye: 2023 Earthquakes Situation Report No. 16, as of 27 April 2023 [EN/TR]

disasters.summary: This bulletin provides an overview of the market prices of commodities in Afghanistan during the 4th week of April 2023. Prices of rice, pulses, and sugar are higher than the 2-year average due to the Eid celebration. The purchasing power of unskilled casual labor and livestock keepers improved due to decreased wheat prices and increased labor wages. The value of Afghani against USD has slightly decreased due to lack of sufficient dollars available due to Eid holidays and closure of the currency market.

metadata.name: Afghanistan: WFP Weekly Market Price Bulletin: Issue 149 (4th Week of April 2023)

disasters.summary: UNHCR is responding to the displacement of South Sudanese refugees from Sudan due to violence. Over 16,600 arrivals have been registered so far, with the majority being South Sudanese returnees. The Government of South Sudan and humanitarian partners are planning for the return of an estimated 180,000 South Sudanese and the arrival of up to 60,000 refugees in the next three months. UNHCR is working closely with partners and governments to respond to the needs of the newly arrived while preparing a joint response plan.

metadata.name: Sudan Situation: UNHCR Emergency Response in South Sudan (29 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 111 new coronavirus cases have been reported in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 378.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (April 28, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: The number of reported COVID-19 cases in the Philippines has been increasing since 27 Feb 2023. From 17 - 23 Apr, 3,148 cases were reported (2.8 cases per 100,000 population). The three regions with the highest case counts were the National Capital Region (1,167 cases), Region IV-A: CALABARZON (501 cases), and Region XI: Davao Region (196 cases).

metadata.name: Philippines Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) Situation Report #126, 24 Apr 2023

disasters.summary: The full-scale war in Ukraine has entered its second year, with over 13.5 million people affected by displacement within and beyond the country’s borders. Despite critical challenges, 5.6 million people have returned to their place of habitual residence. Humanitarian needs remain high, with 17.6 million people in Ukraine and 4.2 million in refugee hosting countries needing assistance. IOM has been providing winterization essentials, fuel, generators, and other support to those affected. The 2023 IOM Appeal for Ukraine and Neighbouring Countries encompasses a comprehensive approach to reaching the most vulnerable, but only 5% of the Appeal has been funded, threatening IOM’s ability to maintain its capacity.

metadata.name: IOM Regional Ukraine Response Situation Report, 27 April 2023

disasters.summary: The Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) for April 28, 2023, Vol. 98, No. 17, contains two articles: one on the WHO's Health Emergencies Programme monthly summary for March 2023, and one on the performance of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance and incidence of poliomyelitis in 2023.

metadata.name: Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER), 28 April 2023, Vol. 98, No. 17, pp. 175–184 [EN/FR]

disasters.summary: The Protection Sector in Syria is responding to the earthquake by evacuating mid-term shelters in Aleppo and closing temporary shelters. Service provision is delayed due to unclear locations for newly established mid-term shelters. Missions to two mid-term shelters have revealed reports of increasing intra-family violence, trauma, and psychological distress. People in the coastal areas have been evacuated from shelters on very short notice.

metadata.name: Syria Earthquake Response: Protection Sector Update - Flash Update #14 as of 27 April 2023

disasters.summary: Conflict in Laas Caanood, Somalia has caused displacement and loss of lives and livelihoods, resulting in urgent relief assistance needs. WFP conducted a rapid food security assessment in the Sool Region of Somalia to capture the current food security situation of the conflict-affected population. The assessment found that food security among the conflict-affected population has deteriorated, with more than 100,000 people in urgent need of humanitarian food and nutrition assistance. Livelihood systems have been disrupted, and households are adopting negative coping strategies such as selling productive assets and reducing the number of meals consumed per day. Markets remain accessible, but food prices have increased. The impact of food stock loss could exacerbate food insecurity for pastoralist IDPs. Critical needs of displaced groups include improved food security, nutrition, livelihood recovery, education, WASH, health, and shelter.

metadata.name: WFP Somalia: Situation Report on Laas Caanood Response

disasters.summary: This UNICEF report highlights the dire humanitarian situation in Sudan due to ongoing fighting. At least 9 children have been killed and 50 injured, and 16 of 34 hospitals in the city have become non-functional. The fighting has disrupted critical care for 50,000 severely malnourished children, and access to food, water, hygiene, and other essential supplies is constrained. Schools and educational institutions are closed, and international aid agency staff have largely been evacuated. UN staff remain in Port Sudan to lead humanitarian operations.

metadata.name: UNICEF Sudan Humanitarian Situation Report No.1 (SAF-RSF Clashes), 25 April 2023

disasters.summary: UNHCR and its partners are providing technical guidance and support to the Republic of Moldova in the registration process for temporary protection of refugees. UNHCR is also providing training to Child Protection Specialists, and has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Moldova State University to educate students about refugees and humanitarian action. Additionally, UNHCR and its partners are providing equipment, training, and non-food items to refugees and host communities.

metadata.name: Ukraine Situation: The Republic of Moldova Operations Update (11 April 2023)

disasters.summary: This report discusses the UNDP programme "Ending Gender-Based Violence and Achieving the Sustainable Development Goals," which piloted approaches to integrating actions to address GBV into large sectoral projects addressing a variety of development goals. It outlines the lessons learned from the four pilot projects, including the need for advocacy, coordination, monitoring, evaluation and learning, and capacity-strengthening. It also highlights the importance of an enabling environment for ethical, safe and effective GBV integration, and the need for project partner and team buy-in and support.

metadata.name: A New Approach to Ending Gender-Based Violence: Lessons on Integrating Prevention and Responses in Four UNDP Sectoral Development Projects

disasters.summary: Violence and conflict in eastern DRC has caused 6 million people to be internally displaced, with 6.1 million people already projected to be experiencing high levels of food insecurity. Intercommunity violence between the Cooperative for the Development of the Congo (CODECO) and Zaire militias in Ituri has caused catastrophic conditions for displaced populations, with shortages of food, nutritional inputs and basic medicines. Malnutrition is rising, and food prices have increased significantly due to the conflict. Humanitarian assistance is urgently needed to prevent further hunger.

metadata.name: Humanitarian Emergency in North Kivu, Ituri and South Kivu in 2023 - Flash Report (26 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, 1.58 million people in southwestern Angola were in acute food insecurity. WFP provided assistance to 13,186 people, including commodity vouchers, nutrition supplements, and school meals. Additionally, 21.4 MT of Ready-to-Use Supplementary Food was distributed. In Huila and Cunene provinces, 35,357 children were screened for Community Management of Acute Malnutrition and 946 families of malnourished children received commodity food vouchers. In Lunda Norte province, 6,458 refugees received assistance from WFP, including food distribution and training on seed banking, collecting rainwater, and animal husbandry.

metadata.name: WFP Angola Country Brief, March 2023

disasters.summary: The International Organisation for Migration, with the support of the Government of Japan, commissioned Samuel Hall to conduct a Labour Market Assessment in the North-West and South-West regions of Cameroon. The assessment aims to identify the needs and challenges of employers, employees, job seekers, and labour market intermediaries in the region, in the context of the Anglophone crisis, to ensure that interventions offered to vulnerable persons and returnees create sustainable livelihoods and youth engagement opportunities. It also seeks to facilitate discussions around conflict-sensitive approaches to peacebuilding programming, the humanitarian-development-peace nexus, social cohesion, and criteria for durable solutions.

metadata.name: Labour Market Survey in NorthWest, South-West Regions of Cameroon for the Humanitarian Development Peace Nexus

disasters.summary: The ongoing conflict in Sudan has caused a disruption in traffic between Sudan and the Central African Republic (CAR), resulting in a sharp increase in the price of basic commodities. This has exacerbated the already existing food insecurity in the northern region of CAR, with an estimated 120,000 people in need of humanitarian assistance. 12,600 Sudanese have crossed the border into CAR and are living in spontaneous settlements. Humanitarian teams have arrived in Birao to provide emergency assistance, including clean water, and the most pressing needs include emergency shelter, food, clean water, and latrines.

metadata.name: Impact of Sudan crisis in the Central African Republic (Flash Update 28 April 2023)

disasters.summary: During the first quarter of 2023, UNICEF provided humanitarian aid to those affected by floods and conflicts in Chad. This included providing nutrition treatment to 53,700 under-5 children, NFI kits to 52,170 people, safe water to 52,092 people, and a riposte immunization campaign that reached 414,250 children.

metadata.name: UNICEF Chad Humanitarian Situation Report No. 1 for 1 January to 31 March 2023

disasters.summary: The UN and humanitarian partners are responding to needs in north-west Syria driven by 12 years of conflict and the impacts of the earthquakes. Over 500,000 people have been supported with multi-cash assistance, and a vaccination campaign against measles and polio was launched in April. At least seven civilians have been killed and 15 injured since the earthquakes struck. The humanitarian community has reached over 275,000 people with emergency tents and Non-Food Item (NFI) kits, and over 16,000 of dignified shelters have been completed. The Syria Earthquake Flash Appeal has secured over 98 per cent of the required funding, but the Syria Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) for 2023 remains largely underfunded.

metadata.name: North-West Syria: Situation Report (28 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, countries under the UNHCR Multi-Country Office in Panama faced risks of detention, trafficking, and gender-based violence. The Aruban Prime Minister highlighted the difficulties in addressing mixed movements, while Amnesty International, Refugee Work Netherlands, and Human Rights Defense Curaçao (HRDC) wrote to the parliaments of Curaçao, Aruba, Saint Maarten and The Netherlands requesting respect for the human rights of refugees and migrants. Belize agreed to visa restrictions on Haitians and increased entry requirements for Jamaicans, while the U.S. Assistant Secretary of State announced that 10,000 Cubans had successfully used the parole program to enter the country. Guyana’s Minister of Foreign Affairs attended the 2023 International Conference in Solidarity with Venezuelan Refugees and Migrants, while Nicaragua was accused of widespread human rights violations. In Panama, the President sanctioned the law that creates the Ministry of Women, while in Suriname, hundreds of protesters gathered to demand the President’s resignation. In Trinidad and Tobago, attorneys called on the Government to adopt international standards to address alleged human rights violations towards refugees and migrants.

metadata.name: Panama Multi-Country Office: Monthly Operational Update (March 2023)

disasters.summary: The Pacific Syndromic Surveillance System Weekly Bulletin for the week of April 17-23, 2023 reported alerts of two cases of varicella and three cases of angina in W&F, as well as one case in Vanuatu. Additionally, the bulletin reported COVID-19 cases in the Cook Islands, RMI, CNMI, FSM, and Solomon Islands.

metadata.name: Pacific Syndromic Surveillance System Weekly Bulletin / Système de Surveillance Syndromique dans le Pacifique - Bulletin Hebdomadaire: W16 2023 (Apr 17-Apr 23)

disasters.summary: This review was conducted to assess the role of donors in the drive for greater accountability to people in crisis. It synthesized existing recommendations and analyzed how donors are currently referencing commitments to Accountability to Affected People (AAP) in their grant and partnership guidelines. The review included a meta review of donor related recommendations, a review of current donors' practices on AAP, and a synthesis report and recommendations for the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) Task Force and IASC to take forward.

metadata.name: Supporting donors’ responsibility for greater accountability to people in crisis: Review of donor AAP commitments, requirements and recommendations

disasters.summary: Fighting in Sudan has caused thousands of people to flee their homes and seek refuge in the Central African Republic. According to estimates, 12,600 people have arrived in the country, and the dynamics of new arrivals are rapidly changing. The Humanitarian Needs Overview estimates that 120,000 people in the northern region are in need of assistance and protection, and the situation is expected to worsen with the rainy season. The humanitarian country team met on 24 April and an interagency mission was deployed to the northern part of the country to assess the needs. It is estimated that up to 50,000 people may arrive in the Central African Republic.

metadata.name: UNICEF Central African Republic Flash Update No. 1 (Impact of Sudan Crisis) as of 28 April 2023

disasters.summary: On International Day of Girls in ICT, UNICEF released a report that found that 90% of adolescent girls and young women in low-income countries are not using the internet, while their male peers are twice as likely to be online. The report highlights the need to empower girls to become innovators, creators, and leaders by providing them with digital skills. It also calls for governments and partners to close the gender divide and ensure that girls have the opportunities to succeed in a digital world, such as teaching digital skills equally to girls and boys, protecting girls' safety online, and promoting girls' access to peer learning and mentoring.

metadata.name: Bridging the Gender Digital Divide: Challenges and an Urgent Call for Action for Equitable Digital Skills Development

disasters.summary: The Ministry of Health and Population in Nepal has instructed hospitals to reserve 10% of beds for poor, helpless, and abandoned patients. In the last 24 hours, 82 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed, bringing the total number of active cases to 361. As the number of infections rises, more people are taking booster doses of the vaccine against the virus.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (April 27, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: This report provides an update on the joint markets and supply chain in Somalia from April 16-22, 2023. Prices of most food and non-food items remained stable in most states, except in Puntland, where prices exhibited mixed trends. Prices of local cereal and imported food items declined in Puntland due to increased supply. Camel milk prices declined in Puntland and Southwest due to improved water supply and replenishing pasture. Labor wage rates and fuel prices remained relatively stable. There was sufficient supply of essential food items in the markets and supply chain resilience was good, except in areas affected by crisis or localized heavy rains. Trade and commodity transportation into Somalia was robust, with most roads being accessible. Food items assortment was broad and milk, meat, fish, fruits, and vegetables were readily available.
