Price drops in camel milk will increase its affordability to market-dependent households, improving protein-rich food intake, especially among children.

metadata.name: Somalia - Joint Markets and Supply Chain Update: 16 - 22 April 2023

disasters.summary: This Weekly Bulletin focuses on public health emergencies occurring in the WHO African region. This week’s articles cover Marburg virus disease in Equatorial Guinea and Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the WHO African region. Major issues and challenges include the report of new confirmed cases of Marburg Virus Disease (MVD) in Equatorial Guinea and the stable COVID-19 epidemiological situation in the WHO African Region. Countries are advised to maintain response actions such as risk communication and community engagement messaging and advocacy.

metadata.name: Weekly Bulletin on Outbreaks and other Emergencies: Week 17: 17-23 April 2023 (Data as reported by: 17:00; 23 April 2023)

disasters.summary: The 2023 First Round Crop and Livestock Report found that the total area planted under all crops increased by 8% from 2021/22 season to 2022/23. Rainfall was less in the southern parts of Zimbabwe, while northern provinces experienced above-normal rainfall. This stability in the cost of the minimum expenditure basket over the last three months has been a relief for poor and vulnerable households.

metadata.name: Zimbabwe - Food Security and Markets Monitoring Report, March 2023

disasters.summary: During the period of January-March 2023, UNHCR Myanmar provided core relief items, shelter support, and cash assistance to 1.8 million internally displaced people in Rakhine, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah and Mon States, and Bago (East), Tanintharyi, Sagaing and Magway Regions. Of these, 95,000 people received core relief items, 11,500 people received shelter support, and 8,300 people with specific needs benefited from cash assistance. An estimated 1.4 million people have been displaced due to the resumption and intensification of clashes between the Tatmadaw and ethnic armed organizations (EAOs) and/or People’s Defense Forces (PDF) since February 2021, with 630,000 of these being Rohingya in Rakhine State, of which some 147,000 are living in displacement camps as well as among the host community since 2012.

metadata.name: UNHCR Myanmar Operational Update, January-March 2023

disasters.summary: WFP has provided food and nutrition assistance to over 118,000 people in 5 of the 8 provinces affected by Cyclone Freddy. WFP is providing multi-modal logistics and transport services to deliver assistance to hard-to-reach areas, and is supporting health services for moderate acute malnutrition treatment. In addition, WFP is supporting people affected by Cyclone Freddy with in-kind food distributions in Tete and Sofala. As of 18 April, over 27,000 cases of cholera have been detected, and over 120 deaths have been reported, with the worst affected province being Zambezia. The government has vaccinated over 1.2 million people.

metadata.name: WFP Mozambique: Cyclone Freddy External Situation Report #11 (20 April 2023 )

disasters.summary: The Syria crisis entered its thirteenth year in March 2023, with an estimated 15.3 million people in need of humanitarian assistance. The 6 February earthquakes further exacerbated the situation, affecting 8.8 million people. UNHCR is responding to this new emergency and continuing to provide protection and assistance to refugees, asylum-seekers, internally displaced people, returnees, stateless people, and host community members.

metadata.name: Syria: UNHCR Operational Update, January - March 2023

disasters.summary: The ongoing conflict in Sudan has caused a disruption in traffic between Sudan and the Central African Republic (CAR), resulting in a sharp increase in the price of basic commodities. This has exacerbated the already existing food insecurity in the northern region of CAR, with an estimated 120,000 people in need of humanitarian assistance and protection. Approximately 3,000 people have crossed the Sudan border into CAR and are living in spontaneous settlements, with more people reportedly waiting at the border. The humanitarian community is assessing its capacity to scale up the response and provide emergency shelters and food.

metadata.name: Impact of Sudan crisis in the Central African Republic (Flash Update 27 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In order to assess the impact of insecurity in hard-to-reach areas of Niger, WFP and national partners conducted a cropland change detection analysis using high-resolution satellite images. The analysis covered nearly 6,500 localities in 5 regions and estimated the number of people living in those districts at over 4.7 million. The analysis compared the situation at the end of 2022 agricultural season with that of the previous year (2021) and a pre-crisis baseline (2016). The results of the analysis were used to inform needs assessments and response planning at the locality level.

metadata.name: Niger: Satellite imagery analysis 2022 - Cropland change detection analysis in hard-to-reach areas

disasters.summary: This external situation report published on 27 April 2023 provides an update on the global multi-country outbreak of mpox (monkeypox). Since the last report, 183 new cases and 14 new related deaths have been reported to WHO. The Western Pacific Region reported an increase in cases in the last three weeks compared to the three weeks prior, and the Eastern Mediterranean region is also highlighted. The incubation period for mpox is estimated to be six to nine days, and WHO is working with Member States to control and interrupt sustained person-to-person transmission of mpox through risk communication and community engagement activities, including on social media.

metadata.name: Multi-country outbreak of mpox (monkeypox) - External Situation Report 21, published 27 April 2023

disasters.summary: As of April 23, 2023, there have been 764 million confirmed cases and 6.9 million deaths from COVID-19 reported globally. In the last 28 days, there has been a 23% decrease in new cases and a 36% decrease in deaths compared to the previous 28 days. However, increases in reported cases and deaths are still seen in some regions and countries. Data presented in this report are incomplete and should be interpreted with caution. WHO COVID-19 dashboard provides a full dataset for download.

metadata.name: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19): Weekly Epidemiological Update (27 April 2023)

disasters.summary: This report covers the period from April 13 to 24, 2023 in Peru, where heavy rains have caused 65,289 people to be without homes, 377,190 people affected, 146,539 households affected, 99 dead and 13 missing. The UN has deployed teams to Lambayeque, Piura and Tumbes to coordinate international cooperation and humanitarian NGOs, and the UN Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) has approved an allocation of US$6.9 million to assist 247,000 people in need.

metadata.name: Peru: Flooding Situation Report No. 04 (as of 24 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In April 2023, satellite imagery revealed a loss of nearly 5,000 hectares of cropland in the Artibonite rice plain compared to 2018, corresponding to the beginning of the socio-political, economic and security crisis in Haiti. The security situation had deteriorated in the department of Artibonite due to the presence of armed groups, leading to the abandonment of crop fields in the communes of Dessalines and Petite-Rivière-de-l'Artibonite. The agricultural workforce moved to cultivate in more secure areas, such as Desdunes and Grande Saline, where new fields were detected. These fields were harvested early, between mid-February and early March, instead of the usual March-April.

metadata.name: Haiti | April 2023 - Cropland change analysis in Artibonite (off-season)

disasters.summary: UNICEF is responding to the conflict in Chad by providing 500 NFI kits, 3,024 bottles of bleach, 100 cartons of RUTF, 14 cartons of Amoxicillin, and medical materials and kits to support existing health services. An agreement with the National Chadian Red Cross (CRT) has been initiated to ensure the deployment of CRT to provide protection services to vulnerable children and their families, as well as communication activities promoting positive behaviors and peace building/social cohesion. As of 27 April, 17 cases of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) are being treated in collaboration with PUI.

metadata.name: UNICEF Chad Humanitarian Flash Update No. 2: 27 April 2023

disasters.summary: In Papua New Guinea, tribal fighting between Aiyala and Nomali tribes has resulted in two deaths and several houses burned down. Humanitarian partners have responded to the violence and an earthquake that occurred in East Sepik province, providing aid to 11,854 IDPs and 70,000 general population. Drought risk status is severe in East New Britain, West New Britain and West Sepik provinces, and the National Disaster Centre has conducted drought assessment missions to the most-affected provinces.

metadata.name: Papua New Guinea: Disaster Management Team Humanitarian Update No. 05 (Updated as of 27th April 2023)

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 136 new coronavirus cases have been reported in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 390.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (April 26, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: Somalia is facing a dire humanitarian crisis due to drought, floods, and conflicts. Approximately 8.3 million people, about half the country’s population, are expected to face Crisis or worse (IPC Phase 3 or above). UNICEF is appealing for US$272.3 million to support humanitarian action in 2023, including providing integrated lifesaving health, nutrition, WASH, education, and child protection interventions. There is a 70 percent funding shortfall of US$5.8 million for the Cholera/AWD response plan. In addition to the funding received in 2023, funds and supplies that were carried over from 2022 have also supported the results achieved so far. The security situation of the country remains volatile, with an estimated 154,000 to 203,000 individuals displaced due to conflict. UNICEF and partners are scaling up their responses across all sectors to meet the rapidly growing needs of the drought, flood and Cholera affected populations in the country.

metadata.name: UNICEF Somalia Humanitarian Situation Report No. 3: 31 March 2023

disasters.summary: In March 2023, Cyclone Freddy and subsequent flooding affected over 1 million people in five provinces in Mozambique. UNICEF provided medicine kits, mosquito nets, and leaner kits to over 30,000 people, and WASH supplies to nearly 300,000 people. UNICEF also trained 63 technical staff and social mobilisers in five provinces on the case area targeted intervention (CATI) approach to cholera prevention and response. Additionally, a cholera outbreak was declared in Quelimane city with 9,082 cases, 3,200 hospitalizations, and 30 deaths. In Cabo Delgado province, there was a relative reduction in the number of conflict-related incidents and new displacements, while return movements continued. UNICEF is appealing for US$113.1 million to sustain the provision of life-saving services for over one million children and families in Mozambique affected by multiple shocks.

metadata.name: UNICEF Mozambique Humanitarian Situation Report No. 3: 31 March 2023

disasters.summary: In January 2023, the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock (MOAL) of Bhutan participated in the Logistics Cluster’s Preparedness Design Workshop in Rome, Italy, and the Ministry of Finance endorsed disaster preparedness activities. Between January and March, the Preparedness Officer coordinated with MoAL and the Department of Local Governance and Disaster Management (DLGDM) to prepare for the Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) development workshop for the national logistics desk. The SOPs will guide the strategic actions of relevant stakeholders in emergency logistics coordination and response.

metadata.name: Bhutan Preparedness - Quarterly Update, January - March 2023

disasters.summary: In January and February 2023, the Government of Tajikistan, with the support of the United Nations World Food Programme and the Global Logistics Cluster’s Field-Based Preparedness Project, organised a National Logistics Preparedness Working Group workshop to finalise the draft national logistics preparedness action plan and develop a national logistics information sharing portal. The Preparedness Officer also participated in a Preparedness Design Workshop in Rome, Italy, and showcased the Logistics Information Exchange Platform and STOCK of Humanitarian Organisations Logistics Mapping with Tajikistan’s logistics data at the NLPWG workshop to obtain feedback.

metadata.name: Tajikistan Preparedness - Quarterly Update, January - March 2023

disasters.summary: In January-March 2023, the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare of Laos (MoLSW) held a consultative meeting with the Food and Drug Department, Ministry of Health, and conducted a biannual National Logistics Preparedness Working Group (NLPWG) Meeting with support from the World Food Programme (WFP) and the Global Logistics Cluster Field-Based Preparedness Project (FBPP). These meetings were part of an ongoing initiative to map relevant national and international actors on importation and customs clearance of humanitarian relief items and streamline relevant mechanisms and processes, as well as discuss progress, challenges, and actions implemented by relevant stakeholders in relation to the National Logistics Preparedness Action Plan and key logistics preparedness priorities in 2023.

metadata.name: Lao PDR Preparedness - Quarterly Update, January - March 2023

disasters.summary: UNHCR and its partners have responded to the worsening humanitarian crisis in north-west Syria, providing core relief items and protection services to those affected by the earthquakes. UNHCR has also increased coordination of the three clusters under its responsibility.

metadata.name: UNHCR Cross-Border Operation for North-West Syria 2023 - January - March 2023

disasters.summary: This Gender Alert focuses on the impact of multiple crises in Ethiopia on women, and their underrepresentation in peace processes and institutional frameworks. It highlights the need for a robust gender-sensitive institutional set-up to ensure more women's engagement in peace and security. UN Women and partners are working with the Government of Ethiopia to develop a National Action Plan for Resolution 1325, with the leadership and ownership of the process by the Ministry for Women and Social Affairs and the Ministry of Peace. The role of women's movement is also paramount.

metadata.name: Humanitarian Gender Alert - Women, peace and security and humanitarian action in context of Ethiopia (April 2023 - Issue 3)

disasters.summary: The 2022 Climate Risk Insurance Annual Report from WFP highlights the achievements of their CRI programmes in 21 countries across Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean. It provides an overview of how WFP is promoting gender equality and women’s empowerment in its programmes, as well as stories from the field and interviews with partners. In 2022, WFP provided financial protection to over 3.8 million people, with payouts of US$12.6 million to support 1.8 million people affected by droughts, floods, and hurricanes.

metadata.name: 2022 Climate Risk Insurance Annual Report

disasters.summary: The security situation in Las Caanood, Somalia remains tense, with 154,230 people displaced from the town due to fighting. UNHCR and its partner, Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), have set up protection helpdesks in Sool, Togdheer and Sanaag regions to identify and support serious protection incidents. NRC has also started community mobilization and engagement processes at site level. In Kalabaydh, UNHCR's partner has visited 300 IDP families in need of emergency shelter, WASH facilities, and protection support.

metadata.name: East and Horn of Africa, and the Great Lakes Region - External Update #2: Las Caanood Situation - Emergency Response in Somalia and Ethiopia (19 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In north-west Syria, a long-standing humanitarian crisis has been exacerbated by earthquakes. UNHCR and its partners have increased the provision of relief items and protection services to those affected, and have strengthened the coordination of the three clusters under their responsibility. 2.7 million people are displaced and 4.1 million are reliant on humanitarian assistance.

metadata.name: North - West Syria: UNHCR Operational Update, January - March 2023

disasters.summary: Over the past week, light to moderate rains were recorded over several parts of Somalia with some areas receiving intense rains of more than 20 mm per day. According to the weekly forecast, several areas in southern, central and northwestern parts of Somalia are expected to observe heavy to very heavy cumulative rainfall during the forecast period, with some areas expected to receive more than 150 mm of rainfall. Dry conditions are expected in northern and eastern parts of Bari region including the coastal areas. High temperatures of between 28°C and 32°C are expected in southern and central parts of the country, and moderate temperatures of between 24°C and 28°C in the northern parts.

metadata.name: Somalia Weekly Weather Forecast - Valid From 26th April to 3rd May 2023

disasters.summary: The World Bank released a report, Rising Strong: Peru Poverty and Equity Assessment, which found that seven in ten Peruvians are poor or at risk of falling into poverty due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The report also found that poverty had decreased from 59 percent to 20 percent between 2004 and 2019, but increased to 26 percent in 2021 due to the pandemic. Additionally, the report found that most of the poor live in urban areas, and that four in ten Peruvians are at risk of falling into poverty. The report includes public policy recommendations to reduce poverty and promote inclusive development, such as promoting access to quality public services, addressing high levels of informality and job insecurity, and closing gender gaps.

metadata.name: Rising Strong: Peru Poverty and Equity Assessment

disasters.summary: The UNHCR Regional Operational Update for West and Central Africa for October-December 2022 highlights the successful resettlement of 5,096 refugees from Niger to third countries, the 16 Days of Activism campaign to eliminate violence against women, and the voluntary repatriation of 316,000 Ivorians linked to the cessation of their refugee status.

metadata.name: UNHCR Regional Operational Update - West and Central Africa Operational Update (October - December 2022)

disasters.summary: On March 9th, 150 asylum seekers were received in Rwanda, bringing the total population of the ETM Centre to 674 individuals. Since November 2022, UNHCR has received 5,876 asylum seekers from the DRC due to the ongoing conflict in the North-eastern part of the country. A field mission was hosted by UNHCR for the heads of the United Nations agencies in Rwanda to the Kirehe District and Mahama Refugee Camp to showcase the situation of refugees and host communities in the district.

metadata.name: UNHCR Operational Update Rwanda, March 2023

disasters.summary: Violent clashes between government forces and nonstate armed groups in the eastern provinces of North Kivu and Ituri in the Democratic Republic of the Congo have caused over 881,000 people to be displaced since March 2022. Many have fled to Goma and South Kivu Province, while others in locations such as Beni and Bunia are facing escalating violence and human rights violations. The humanitarian response is being scaled up to address the urgent needs of the displaced.

metadata.name: Democratic Republic of the Congo: Emergency Update (13 - 26 March 2023)

disasters.summary: This report provides an overview of the risks, current state of inclusive insurance and disaster risk finance, and recommendations to advance these areas in the United Republic of Tanzania. Risks include floods, drought, earthquakes, disease outbreak and marine accidents. Inclusive insurance is supported by government and regulatory bodies, with at least five insurance companies offering microinsurance products. Disaster risk finance is coordinated by the Disaster Management Department, with the Government shouldering the costs of disasters. Recommendations include enhancing market-based research and development activities for inclusive insurance, assisting the Tanzania Insurance Regulatory Authority to enhance the enabling environment, building industry capacity, developing risk information and modelling systems, and developing a comprehensive disaster risk financing strategy.

metadata.name: Inclusive insurance and risk financing in the United Republic of Tanzania: Snapshot and way forward 2023

disasters.summary: This report provides an update on the protection situation of refugees from Ukraine, based on data from 17,708 interviews conducted in Hungary, Moldova, Poland, Romania, and Slovakia between October 2022 and mid-February 2023. The data is supplemented by results from focus group discussions with refugee communities and other exercises conducted by UNHCR and partners. The report is intended to provide an update on the results of UNHCR’s 2022 protection monitoring report on the situation of refugees from Ukraine, as well as a partial update of UNHCR’s report ‘The Implementation of the Temporary Protection Directive: Six Months On’.

metadata.name: Displacement Patterns, Protection Risks and Needs of Refugees from Ukraine - Regional Protection Analysis # 2

disasters.summary: On 30 March, 100,000 Venezuelans had been relocated from the North of Brazil to other parts of the country since 2018. 15 elderly people were welcomed at the Casa de Acolhida – Jardim Paraíso, a reception service of the Nova Iguaçu Municipal Secretariat of Social Assistance. This is the second group of elderly Venezuelans hosted at the site, which has been in operation since 2020 and is supported by federal and municipal resources. Elderly people face additional barriers in accessing durable solutions, such as xenophobia, lack of digital inclusion, and ageism.

metadata.name: UNHCR Brazil - Interiorization Report - January to March 2023 [EN/PT]

disasters.summary: The UNHCR is responding to the emergency in Ukraine, where shelling has damaged hospitals and injured health workers. As of April 18, there have been 22,904 civilian casualties since Russia's invasion, including 765 in March. The IAEA Director General has warned of a major risk to nuclear safety and security due to the dependence of Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant on a single functioning power line. Air and missile strikes continue, with a missile strike on Sloviansk killing at least eight civilians on April 14. The Ministry of Defence of Ukraine has noted that the fiercest battles are fought for Bakhmut and Mar’yinka.

metadata.name: Ukraine Emergency: UNHCR Operational Response, Delivery Updates (19 April 2023) [EN/UK]

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 113 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 362. The Ministry of Health and Population has urged the public to get vaccinated, and President Ramchandra Paudel is undergoing further health examinations with his condition gradually improving.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (April 25, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: The Turkish Ministry of Interior reported that 20% of people who had relocated due to the earthquake are returning, likely due to financial constraints. UNHCR has also observed an increase in refugees returning to the affected provinces for similar reasons. To meet the needs of the returning population, authorities are strengthening shelter capacity and debris removal is expected to be completed by 21 April, except in Hatay.

metadata.name: UNHCR Türkiye Earthquake Emergency Response (20 April 2023)

disasters.summary: The economies of Albania, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Kosovo, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Serbia have surpassed pre-pandemic levels despite multiple economic shocks, according to the latest Western Balkans Regular Economic Report. GDP growth is expected to moderate to 2.6 percent in 2023, driven by private consumption, exports, and public investment. Inflation has surged to a two-decade high, and price pressures remain elevated, affecting low-income households severely. Employment growth has slowed, and the outlook for the Western Balkans remains positive, though reforms are needed to accelerate the green transition and to address key structural challenges.

metadata.name: Western Balkans Regular Economic Report No.23 (Spring 2023): Testing Resilience [EN/SQ/RS]

disasters.summary: The Shelter Cluster in Yemen has received 11% of its 2023 funding requirements and has so far reached 164,000 IDPs, returnees, and vulnerable host with various shelter assistance. The Cluster has developed a Flood Preparedness and Response plan to respond to the most vulnerable IDPs and conducted two information management refresher sessions. However, there is a lack of funding to support longer-term shelter solutions and eviction threats are rising in IDP hosting sites.

metadata.name: Shelter Cluster Factsheet for Q1 2023 (January - March 2023)

disasters.summary: Fighting between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) has been ongoing since April 15th, 2023, resulting in over 427 deaths and 3,700 injuries. Civilians are fleeing to Chad, Egypt and South Sudan, with nearly 4,000 people registered moving from Sudan to South Sudan as of 24 April. Humanitarian partners in South Sudan are scaling up their presence in key response areas and preparing an emergency response to address the needs of the most vulnerable people. The new arrivals are in need of food and health screenings.

metadata.name: Impact of Sudan Crisis on South Sudan Flash Update No. 1 (As of 25 April 2023)

disasters.summary: The Nevado del Ruiz volcano in Colombia has been upgraded to orange activity level, indicating a higher probability of eruption in the near future. This could potentially affect 57,000 people, including 17,000 children and adolescents. The UNGRD has requested the local governments to evacuate 2,500 families, and the ICBF has prepared a contingency plan with food stocks and Mobile Units teams. The Ministry of Education has identified 60 educational institutions and 55,000 students that could be affected, and the Ministry of Housing, City and Territory has issued an information circular regarding WASH sector measures.

metadata.name: UNICEF Colombia Humanitarian Flash Note No. 1 (Nevado del Ruiz Volcano) for 22 April 2023.

disasters.summary: UNICEF is supporting the Ministry of Education in Malawi to ensure the safe reopening of schools through a back-to-school campaign. Over the last two weeks, 94,676 children under five were screened for acute malnutrition, of whom 293 were identified with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) and referred for treatment. 45,169 people have been reached with safe water as a result of the rehabilitation of water points and the provision of water treatment solutions. UNICEF has secured USD 16.2 million for the 2023 HAC target of USD 52.4 million, leaving a USD 36.2 million (69%) funding gap. In total, 5.9 million people, 2.95 million children, 659,278 internally displaced people, and 3.068 million women and girls are in need of humanitarian assistance.

metadata.name: UNICEF Malawi Humanitarian Situation Report No. 3 for 1-15 April 2023.

disasters.summary: In Honduras, 247,090 people were internally displaced between 2004 and 2018 due to violence. In December 2022, the National Congress of Honduras approved the Law for the Prevention, Care and Protection of Internally Displaced Persons, which was officially promulgated in March 2023. This law provides a comprehensive response to internal displacement, including early warning systems, prevention and contingency plans, humanitarian assistance, protection of rights, seed capital, and access to justice. It also creates the National Forced Displacement Response System to oversee the implementation of the law.

metadata.name: Honduras - IDP Law - April 2023

disasters.summary: The World Health Organization's Thailand Weekly Situation Update No. 262 reported 4,730,490 confirmed cases and 33,947 total deaths. From 15-22 April 2022, the daily average numbers reported were 155 new confirmed cases per day (including hospital admissions only) and 1 death per day. The main messages are to continue to reduce community transmission of COVID-19, encourage COVID-free settings and booster vaccinations, and to get vaccinated, maintain universal precautions, and stay informed.

metadata.name: COVID-19 WHO Thailand Weekly Situation Update No. 262 - 25 April 2023

disasters.summary: This weekly report provides an overview of the rainfall, water levels, and drought conditions in the Lower Mekong River Basin from April 18-24, 2023. Rainfall was observed in some areas, while temperatures are expected to be warm and rainfall below average for the next 7 days. Water levels at most monitoring stations are below their long-term average value, except at Luang Prabang, Thakhek, Savannakhet, Stung Treng and Kratie and Koh Khel. Drought conditions are expected to remain in some areas in the upper, middle, and lower parts of the basin, with average rainfall forecasted for April and severe dryness in May in the 3S area.

metadata.name: Weekly Dry Season Situation Report in the Lower Mekong River Basin - 18-24 April 2023

disasters.summary: Oromia Region is facing multiple health related challenges due to drought and floods, including outbreaks of measles and cholera. Health cluster partners are responding to the public health threats with support from OCHA, including a measles vaccination campaign in West Wollega Zone and the delivery of cholera drugs and supplies to Guji Zone. The Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund is also providing essential health services to 19,000 people displaced by flash floods in Borena Zone. A multi-sectoral drought impact assessment was conducted in West Hararghe Zone, identifying over 72,000 households in need of assistance.

metadata.name: Health response and preparedness in Oromia Region (25 April 2023)

disasters.summary: Fighting between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) has been ongoing since 15 April 2023, resulting in at least 427 deaths and over 3,700 injuries. There are also reports of deaths and injuries among refugees and IDPs, as well as looting of humanitarian supplies and warehouses. On 24 April, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced a 72-hour ceasefire between the warring factions, starting at midnight on 24 April.

metadata.name: Sudan Situation - UNHCR External Update #2 - 25 April 2023

disasters.summary: Heavy fighting between the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) has been ongoing for 11 days, despite multiple agreements for ceasefires. The human toll of the crisis is devastating, with 459 people killed and more than 4,000 injured, mostly civilians. Humanitarian assets and offices have been looted, and five aid workers have been killed. At least 75,000 people have been internally displaced in Sudan, and thousands more have fled to neighboring countries. IOM is calling on all parties to ensure the safety of humanitarians and allow their unrestricted access to be able to assist those most vulnerable, and is appealing for the restoration of calm and dialogue to resolve the crisis and enable humanitarian aid.

metadata.name: Sudan: Escalating Conflict Situation Update 25 April 2023

disasters.summary: This Live Wire provides evidence of how clean cooking solutions are gaining ground in refugee camps and other displacement settlements around the world. It discusses how new operating models can improve affordability and suggests that clean cooking should be integrated into basic service packages provided to displaced populations.

metadata.name: Breaking Barriers: Improving Access to Clean Cooking in Displacement Settings

disasters.summary: The Nepalese government is launching a week-long immunization campaign targeting deprived children, while 81 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the last 24 hours. There are currently 370 active cases in the country, and the health condition of President Ramchandra Paudel, who is receiving treatment in India, has improved gradually.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (April 24, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: In March 2023, WFP provided assistance to 7.3 million people in Yemen, 17 million of whom were food insecure and 6.1 million in IPC Phase 4 (Emergency). Food security data showed that the prevalence of inadequate food consumption remained stable for the third consecutive month, with food prices increasing in the south and decreasing in the north. Hostilities between IRG and SBA forces escalated in late March, but no airstrikes or cross-border aerial attacks have been reported since the truce started in April 2022.

metadata.name: WFP Yemen Situation Report #3, March 2023

disasters.summary: This week, there were 378 new RT-PCR confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Nepal, with the majority (210 cases) coming from Kathmandu district and 68.5% (259 cases) from the Kathmandu Valley. Of the total RT-PCR confirmed cases, 98.7% (989,779) have recovered, 0.01% (378) are active cases, and 1.19% (12,022) are deaths.

metadata.name: Situation Update #157 - Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) WHO Country Office for Nepal Reporting Date: 10 - 16 April 2023 (Epi Week 15)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, WFP provided life-saving humanitarian food assistance to 3.5 million people in Somalia, including 3.4 million people who received cash-based transfers or in-kind support and 142,000 vulnerable drought-affected people. Nutrition support was provided to 888,000 people, including children under five and pregnant and lactating women. 27,000 people were reached with first line assistance in Adan Yaabal, a district made newly accessible following government-led military operations. The ongoing drought is about to become the longest in Somalia’s history, with 6.5 million people projected to face Crisis-level or worse food insecurity between April and June 2023. 1.8 million children under five years are estimated to suffer from acute malnutrition in 2023, while 478,000 of them are likely to be facing life-threatening severe malnutrition. Early seasonal climate forecasts indicate a 50 percent likelihood of a potential onset of a sixth below-average rainy season from March–June 2023.

metadata.name: WFP Somalia: Famine Prevention Response Situation Report (March 2023)

disasters.summary: In Ethiopia, food distributions and humanitarian aid have begun in Afar, Amhara and Tigray regions due to drought, floods and an alarming spread of infectious diseases, including a cholera outbreak that puts 3.3 million people at high-risk. Over 3 million people have been prioritized for response in the Government and partners' four-month (April-July) Drought Response Operational Action Plan. Humanitarian supplies are being moved to assist people in need across the three regions, with over 50% of the targeted 663,600 people in need in Afar having received food assistance, and close to 39,000 people out of the targeted 1.48 million people in Amhara having benefited. In Tigray, more than 125,000 people of the targeted beneficiaries (2.9 million) have received food assistance. Additionally, a measles outbreak has been reported in six woredas of Afar, Oromia (West Wollega), and Tigray, with 65 new suspected cases reported as of April 18th. Resources are needed for measles response, including vaccines, medicine, medical supplies, social mobilization, training of health workers, and case-finding. The drought situation is still dire, with high levels of food insecurity,

metadata.name: Ethiopia - Situation Report, 24 Apr 2023

disasters.summary: In 2023, Haiti is facing political instability, reconstruction and recovery efforts from the 2021 earthquake, severe food insecurity, concerning malnutrition rates, growing violence, an ongoing fuel crisis, and vulnerability to natural hazards. UNICEF is providing basic services such as WASH, education, health, nutrition, child protection, and social protection services. UNICEF requires US$210.3 million to ensure life-saving humanitarian support for women and children in Haiti, but there is a funding gap of US$186.8 million.

metadata.name: UNICEF Haiti Humanitarian Situation Report N.1: January - February 2023

disasters.summary: UNHCR Romania is providing support to refugees from Ukraine in Romania during a transitional period. Key priorities include providing information desks, increased support for refugees with specific needs, enhanced engagement with municipalities, and enhanced counselling and support. The cash working group is considering a one-off assistance to bridge the housing and other needs' gap. UN Agencies are also liaising with authorities to ensure that the new support system is accessible to all. As of 16 April 2023, 128,618 refugees have been granted temporary protection in Romania, with 101,341 refugees in Romania and 65,000 refugees assisted since 2022.

metadata.name: UNHCR Romania: Ukraine Refugee Situation Update, Update #43, 21 April 2023

disasters.summary: In 2021, the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Afghanistan led to increased cross border movement of Afghans seeking protection and asylum in neighboring countries. As of the end of 2022, UNICEF had provided critical support to Afghans and host community members in the neighbouring countries, reaching over 350,000 children with access to education and more than 325,000 children vaccinated against measles. UNICEF appealed for US$81.2 million to meet the needs of Afghan children and their families in 2022, but there was a funding gap of US$30.7 million (38 per cent). In 2023, US$66.2 million is required to continue support 1.9 million people, including 1.1 million children with essential services.

metadata.name: UNICEF Afghanistan Outflow Humanitarian Situation Report No.2 (1 January - 31 December 2022)

disasters.summary: This UNICEF Türkiye Humanitarian Situation Report No. 9 (Earthquake) provides an overview of the situation in Türkiye following the 6 February earthquakes. It highlights the key needs of the affected population, including access to adequate water and sanitation, access to information on available services and social protection schemes, and support for people with disabilities. It also provides an overview of the humanitarian response, including the number of people in need, the number of people targeted by UNICEF, and the funding gap. UNICEF is leading the WASH sector group and has established partnerships with eight municipalities and the Union of Municipalities of Türkiye to deliver immediate humanitarian assistance to affected children and families. The Government is leading the overall humanitarian response, with UNICEF leading the Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and Education sector working groups and co-leading the Child Protection sub-working group. An Interagency Appeal for US$1 billion to assist 5.2 million people affected by the earthquakes is only 29.3% funded.

metadata.name: UNICEF Türkiye Humanitarian Situation Report No. 9 (Earthquake), 17 April 2023

disasters.summary: The Greater Horn of Africa (GHoA) countries have experienced five failed rainy seasons, resulting in 46 million people facing crisis level of food insecurity and 11.6 million internally displaced persons. 11.9 million children under five years old are likely to face acute malnutrition in 2023 and nearly 2.9 million children der five years old will require SAM treatment. Cholera and measles outbreaks have been reported in three and seven countries respectively, and the Sudan Virus Ebola outbreak has been declared over in Uganda. WHO has provided support in terms of health sector coordination, technical and financial support, and drugs and supplies.

metadata.name: Situation Report: Greater Horn of Africa Food Insecurity and Health - Grade 3 Emergency — 1 January 2023 - 1 February 2023

disasters.summary: In Peru, flooding has affected 377,190 people, damaged 146,539 homes, left 65,289 without homes and caused 99 deaths. In Haiti, 70 people have been killed in violent clashes from 14-19 April, and in Colombia, 29,000 people have been affected by mass displacement or confinement and 78,000 people have been affected by climate-related disasters so far in 2023. In Venezuela, 365,000 people have been reached with assistance in January and February 2023, and the Humanitarian Response Plan 2022/2023 requires US$720 million to reach 5.2 million people. The UN Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) has approved a US$6.9 million allocation for urgent response actions to assist 247,000 people in need in Peru.

metadata.name: Latin America & The Caribbean Weekly Situation Update (As of 24 April 2023)

disasters.summary: Food price inflation remains high around the world, with the most-affected countries being in Africa, North America, Latin America, South Asia, Europe, and Central Asia. The FAO Food Price Index declined for the 12th consecutive month in March 2023, and the NOAA Climate Prediction Center has issued an El Niño Watch. Trade-related policies imposed by countries have surged, and up to 205 million people are expected to face acute food insecurity in 45 countries.

metadata.name: Food Security Update (April 20, 2023)

disasters.summary: In Haiti, access to health care is severely limited due to insecurity, lack of local health facilities, and cost of care. This has led to a decrease in the population's use of health services, creating a risk of epidemics. The Haitian health system is mainly funded by citizens and international aid, and the share of health in the national budget has decreased in recent years. Gang violence has forced some hospitals to close, and residents of Brooklyn, Haiti have been trapped in a gang conflict that has resulted in 70 deaths and 40 injuries. Internally displaced persons (IDPs) living in makeshift sites in PAPMA are facing a lack of access to health care due to the absence of functioning medical facilities nearby. Health facilities in Haiti are struggling to remain open due to a lack of qualified staff, equipment, and inputs, as well as an increase in fuel prices. Over the past three years, the use of health services by the population in Haiti has decreased significantly due to the country's periods of crisis. Cholera resurfaced in Haiti in October 2022, and there is a risk of measles and polio outbreaks due to lack of diagnosis and medical assistance.

metadata.name: Haïti : Humanitarian note - Series - New paradigm Issue 2: The impact of violence on access to health care 23 April 2023

disasters.summary: This week, 420 new RT-PCR confirmed cases of COVID-19 were reported in Nepal, with the majority (61.7%) coming from the Kathmandu Valley. Of the total RT-PCR confirmed cases, 98.7% have recovered, 0.01% are active cases, and 1.19% are deaths.

metadata.name: Situation Update #158 - Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) WHO Country Office for Nepal Reporting Date: 17 - 23 April 2023 (Epi Week 16)

disasters.summary: Mozambique has been affected by Tropical Cyclone Freddy, floods, and cholera, with over one million people affected and 314 deaths. 385,930 people have been reached with some form of humanitarian assistance, but stocks and pipelines are running low. The cholera outbreak continues to spread, with 27,353 cases reported in 53 districts across nine provinces. The Humanitarian Response Plan Addendum was published, aiming to support 815,000 people affected by the triple crisis, with a financial requirement of U$138 million.

metadata.name: Mozambique: Tropical Cyclone Freddy, Floods and Cholera - Situation Report No.2

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 103 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 397. Additionally, the health condition of President Ramchandra Paudel, who is being treated in New Delhi, India, is improving.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (April 21, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: This article from the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) provides an update on the 2021-2022 outbreak of wild poliovirus type 1 in southeastern Africa.

metadata.name: Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER), 14 April 2023, Vol. 98, No. 16, pp. 167–174 [EN/FR]

disasters.summary: The Education Sector Working Group in Pakistan has reached 43.6% of its target of 700,000 people with education assistance under the Floods Response Plan. Funding for the emergency response stands at 28 million of the total ask of $40.6m. There is an urgent need to sustain and scale up access to learning, and over 41,000 children in KP and Balochistan have been supported so far. RRP partners are contributing to refugee education in refugee villages and hosting communities for over 129,000 children.

metadata.name: Pakistan: Education Sector Working Group (EIE) Bulletin March 2023

disasters.summary: Türkiye has been in a state of emergency since February, when two devastating earthquakes struck the Kahramanmaraş province, resulting in 50,339 deaths and extensive damage to 307,000 buildings and 893,000 independent units. 22,500 aftershocks have occurred since then, and six additional provinces have been declared disaster areas due to the presence of moderately and heavily damaged buildings.

metadata.name: Türkiye earthquake: External situation report no. 7: 3 - 16 April 2023

disasters.summary: As of April 18th, 2021, 8,172,189 individual refugees from Ukraine have been recorded across Europe, with 5,044,039 registered for temporary protection or similar national protection schemes. Additionally, an estimated 5,352,000 internally displaced people (IDPs) are in Ukraine. UNHCR recently published a Regional Protection Analysis #2 which found that 22% of refugee households have at least one member with specific needs, and 27% of refugees are employed in low-paying jobs due to language barriers and non-recognition of qualifications. Recommendations include early identification of people at heightened risk, addressing barriers to decent employment, and disseminating information about refugee rights in the labour market. More information can be found on the UNHCR Ukraine Emergency website.

metadata.name: Ukraine Situation Flash Update #45 (21 April 2023)

disasters.summary: This weekly bulletin provides an update on the Pacific Syndromic Surveillance System for the week of April 10th to April 16th, 2023. Alerts include Varicella in W&F, Samoa, and COVID-19 in Cook Islands, RMI, CNMI, FSM, Niue, Palau and Cook Islands. Additionally, Influenza-like Illness (ILI) was reported in Niue and Diarrhoea in FSM.

metadata.name: Pacific Syndromic Surveillance System Weekly Bulletin / Système de Surveillance Syndromique dans le Pacifique - Bulletin Hebdomadaire: W15 2023 (Apr 10 - Apr 16)

disasters.summary: On April 15th, 2023, heavy fighting broke out between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Khartoum and Merowe in the Northern State. The UN Secretary General (UNSG) has issued several statements condemning the violence and calling for those responsible to be brought to justice. Regional bodies IGAD and the African Union have also issued statements. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has called for an immediate cessation to hostilities and the UNSG has attended a virtual meeting organized by the African Union to discuss ways the international community can help end the violence. UNHCR has 481 staff members in Sudan and all are accounted for.

metadata.name: Sudan Situation: External Update #1 - East and Horn of Africa, and the Great Lakes Region (20 April 2023)

disasters.summary: This bulletin provides an overview of the market prices of main commodities in Afghanistan during the third week of April 2023. Prices of rice, pulses, and sugar are high compared to the two-year average, and are expected to increase due to the approaching Eid. The purchasing power of unskilled casual labour and livestock keepers improved due to decreased wheat prices, increased labour wage, and increased sheep price. The value of Afghani against USD is slightly improved due to Zakat in Ramadan and more remittances from outside for Eid preparation, but is still lower than last year's same time and average level.

metadata.name: Afghanistan: WFP Weekly Market Price Bulletin: Issue 148 (3rd Week of April 2023)

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 108 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 386. The Ministry of Health and Population has requested for a mandatory isolation period of seven days for those infected with COVID-19.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (April 20, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: In north-east Nigeria, an estimated 4.3 million people are at risk of severe hunger during the lean season (June-August) due to years of conflict and violence, the 2022 floods, and the Central Bank of Nigeria’s currency re-design policy. In addition, very high levels of inflation and petrol scarcity have caused a spike in the cost of transportation and other commodities, further exacerbating the food insecurity. US$1.3 billion is required to reach 6 million people in north-east Nigeria with humanitarian assistance in 2023.

metadata.name: Nigeria Situation Report, 20 Apr 2023

disasters.summary: On 5 March 2023, a fire broke out in Rohingya refugee Camp 11 in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh. The fire was brought under control by 5 pm, and the Refugee Relief and Repatriation Commissioner (RRRC) took charge. Humanitarian partners and Rohingya Community Volunteers arrived to assess the damage and coordinate an effective response. No fatalities have been reported.

metadata.name: Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh: Humanitarian Response to the Fire in Rohingya Refugee Camp 11 (20 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, Somalia experienced flash floods in flood prone areas following light to moderate rains. A new report suggests that 43,000 "excess deaths" may have occurred in 2022 due to the deepening drought, with half of these deaths among children under 5. Renewed conflict in Lascanood has resulted in 80 deaths and displacement of 30,000 people. The current drought crisis is compounded by climate change-induced extreme weather, political instability, and insecurity, leading to a surge in disease outbreaks, including cholera and measles. Cholera cases have been reported in 26 of the 74 drought affected districts, with the majority of cases treated in Benadir hospital CTC, Belethawo CTC and Kismayo hospital CTC.

metadata.name: Somalia: Health Cluster Bulletin, March 2023

disasters.summary: During the reporting period, a devastating fire broke out in Rohingya refugee Camp 11, affecting 15,926 people including 8,122 children and damaging 25 UNICEF-supported facilities. UNICEF provided life-saving support to 8,070 people and reconstruction of the affected facilities is underway. With UNICEF support, 163,132 children are receiving education based on the Myanmar Curriculum in Cox's Bazar Rohingya refugee Camps and 9,470 children in 28 schools in Bhasan Char. A Stabilization Center, infant and young child feeding, and Early Childhood Care and Development corners were established in a 20-bed hospital in Bhasan Char to treat children with severe acute malnutrition and provide nutrition counseling. The security situation remains unpredictable and unstable in the Rohingya refugee camps.

metadata.name: UNICEF Bangladesh Humanitarian Situation Report No. 63: 31 March 2023

disasters.summary: Two cyclones, Cheneso and Freddy, hit Madagascar between January 19 and March 03, 2023, causing widespread flooding and destruction. 90,000 people were directly impacted by Cheneso and 187,400 by Freddy, including 88,000 displaced, 47 killed and 20 missing. UNICEF provided emergency water and sanitation services to 21,200 people, and treated 5,577 girls and 5,358 boys for severe acute malnutrition. UNICEF launched a US$ 41.12 million appeal for 2023 to meet the most urgent humanitarian needs of children and women, and as of 31 March 2023, 27% had been received. Parallel crises in the south (drought) and the COVID response (vaccination) remain of concern.

metadata.name: UNICEF Madagascar Humanitarian Situation Report (Cyclone FREDDY & CHENESO): 31 March 2023

disasters.summary: The WHO Country Office in Ukraine, supported by the European Union, Canada, Switzerland, the United States, and Germany, has been delivering medical supplies and medicines to hospitals and medical facilities in the Donetsk, Kharkiv, and Zaporizhzhya regions. On 5 April, the WHO Country Office held a seminar in Cherkasy to improve the emergency medical care and disaster medicine system in Ukraine. As of 18 April, 1564 households and 330 houses remain flooded due to seasonal water level rise in the Volyn, Dnipropetorvsk, Zhytomyr, Kyiv, Kirovograd, Rivna, Poltava, Cherkasy, and Chernihiv regions. UN provided shelter materials and other vital items to 1500 people in a community along the Dripro River in Kherson. According to a sociological research result, 9 out of 10 Ukrainians experienced at least one of the symptoms of psycho traumatization due to the war. The National Health Service of Ukraine and WHO are working on developing primary medical care, strategic procurement and medium-term contracts, and management of the Medical Guarantee Program.

metadata.name: War in Ukraine: Situation report from WHO Ukraine country office. Issue No. 50, 19 April 2023

disasters.summary: Immunization has saved countless lives and is a key part of achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. In Europe and Central Asia, an estimated 931,000 children have missed out on routine immunization from 2019 to 2021. Vaccine hesitancy, weak health systems, and the COVID-19 pandemic have all contributed to this. To protect every child against vaccine-preventable diseases, political will is needed to ensure immunization remains a priority and to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of planning, budgeting and service delivery.

metadata.name: The State of the World’s Children 2023: For Every Child, Vaccination - Regional Brief: Europe and Central Asia

disasters.summary: Immunization has saved countless lives and has led to the eradication of smallpox and the near-eradication of polio. The COVID-19 pandemic has demonstrated the power of immunization, but 19.5 million children in West and Central Africa have missed out on routine immunization from 2019 to 2021. To ensure that these children catch up with their vaccinations, political will is needed to prioritize immunization and invest in health budgets. Immunization is key to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and can generate strong returns on investment.

metadata.name: The State of the World’s Children 2023: For Every Child, Vaccination - Regional Brief: West and Central Africa

disasters.summary: Immunization has saved countless lives and is essential for children to live lives free of disability and illness. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the importance of immunization, but an estimated 67 million children globally have missed out on routine immunization from 2019 to 2021, including 6.8 million in Latin America and the Caribbean. The pandemic has exacerbated this trend, and inequities have been highlighted. To protect every child against vaccine-preventable diseases, political will is needed globally, nationally and locally, and immunization must remain a priority in health budgets.

metadata.name: The State of the World’s Children 2023: For Every Child, Vaccination - Regional Brief: Latin America and the Caribbean

disasters.summary: Immunization has saved countless lives and has led to the eradication of smallpox. The power of immunization was demonstrated again in the COVID-19 pandemic, with two thirds of the world's population immunized against it. However, an estimated 67 million children globally and 13.9 million in South Asia have missed out on routine immunization from 2019 to 2021. The pandemic has exposed and exacerbated weaknesses in health systems and primary health care, and has highlighted the difficulties facing women health workers. To protect every child against vaccine-preventable diseases, political will is needed globally, nationally, and locally. Immunization is key to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, and it makes economic sense as it generates strong returns on investment. Governments and donors need to work together to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of planning, budgeting and service delivery.

metadata.name: The State of the World’s Children 2023: For Every Child, Vaccination - Regional Brief: South Asia

disasters.summary: Immunization has saved countless lives and has led to the eradication of smallpox. The power of immunization was demonstrated again in the COVID-19 pandemic, with two thirds of the world's population immunized against it. However, an estimated 67 million children globally and 12 million in Eastern and Southern Africa have missed out on routine immunization. To ensure these children catch up with their vaccinations, political will is needed to prioritize immunization and invest in health budgets. This will help to reduce future healthcare costs and support economic growth.

metadata.name: The State of the World’s Children 2023: For Every Child, Vaccination - Regional Brief: Eastern and Southern Africa

disasters.summary: This Policy Research Working Paper examines the link between slow-onset climate phenomena such as droughts and urbanization. Using panel data from 1985-2014, the paper shows that drought leads to faster urban growth, with a hypothetical drought lasting 12 months associated with a 27 percent increase in the average annual increment of built-up area. The paper also uses data from several Sahelian cities to illustrate that much of this growth takes the form of non-infill development.

metadata.name: Policy Research Working Paper 10408: After Big Droughts Come Big Cities - Does Drought Drive Urbanization?

disasters.summary: This report covers three weeks of developments in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, including an incident on 18 April in which two Israelis were shot and injured in East Jerusalem. During this period, six Palestinians, including one child, were killed by Israeli forces in the West Bank, and 563 Palestinians were injured in various incidents. Israeli settlers caused damage to residential and agricultural properties, tractors, crops, and a water network, and injured 17 Palestinians, including three children. Israeli forces imposed movement restrictions on two Palestinian villages, and demolished ten Palestinian structures in Area C of the West Bank. Palestinian armed groups fired 52 rockets and other projectiles towards Israel, and Israeli forces launched multiple airstrikes in response.

metadata.name: Occupied Palestinian territory: Protection of Civilians Report | 28 March - 17 April 2023

disasters.summary: Globally, there has been a 27% decrease in new cases and a 32% decrease in deaths in the last 28 days compared to the previous 28 days. However, increases in reported cases and deaths have been seen in the South-East Asia and Eastern Mediterranean regions and in several individual countries. As of 16 April 2023, over 763 million confirmed cases and over 6.9 million deaths have been reported globally. The highest numbers of new 28-day cases were reported from the United States of America, the Republic of Korea, the Russian Federation, France, and Brazil. The highest numbers of new 28-day deaths were reported from the United States of America, Brazil, the Russian Federation, Germany, and the Islamic Republic of Iran.

metadata.name: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19): Weekly Epidemiological Update (20 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In March 2023, the National Migration Service in Panama resumed bus transfers from Darien to Chiriquí following two traffic accidents involving refugees and migrants. The Human Rights Committee expressed concern regarding reports of killings, disappearances, sexual violence, and other crimes in Darien, and the Minister of Government indicated that Panama is aware of its pending commitments related to human rights matters. As of March 2023, 87,400 people had entered irregularly through Darien, and the UNHCR's monthly protection monitoring exercise showed that three out of ten interviewed left their country of origin due to threats or directed attacks against them or their families.

metadata.name: UNHCR Panama Mixed Movements, Darién and Chiriquí (March 2023)

disasters.summary: This report covers the humanitarian situation and response to the earthquakes in Türkiye from 14 to 20 April 2023. 9.1 million people have been affected, with 5.2 million targeted for humanitarian assistance and 3 million people having to relocate from their homes. An estimated 1.6 million people are living in informal settlements with limited access to services. Difficult weather conditions, including heavy rain and flooding, strong winds, and increasingly hot weather in some areas, are posing additional challenges to the humanitarian response. Earthquakes have also occurred across several provinces. The response is being led by the Government of Türkiye in coordination with Türkiye’s national disaster management authority (AFAD) and with support from the Turkish Red Crescent.

metadata.name: Türkiye: 2023 Earthquakes Situation Report No. 15, as of 20 April 2023 [EN/TR]

disasters.summary: The Regional Monitoring Framework for Students on the Move in Latin America and the Caribbean (RMF) is a UNESCO initiative developed in collaboration with 18 ministries of education in the region to ensure the right to education for people on the move. The RMF is composed of complementary quantitative and qualitative elements to understand how the right to education is guaranteed. It includes a set of comparable and relevant statistical indicators, a normative map of national policies, an inventory of innovative experiences and promising practices, and a section on policy implementation analysis. The implementation of the RMF is based on the creation of an environment for dialogue, knowledge sharing, and advocacy related to the right to education for people on the move.

metadata.name: The Regional Monitoring Framework for Students on the Move in Latin America and the Caribbean

disasters.summary: In response to the war in Ukraine, the FAO provided temporary grain storage solutions, vegetable seeds, seed potatoes, and cash assistance to rural households. Through its 2023 Response Programme, the FAO requires USD 205 million to assist rural households and small-scale farmers by providing generators, seeds, and other agricultural production inputs. As of 20 April 2023, the FAO has mobilized USD 30.5 million, leaving a gap of USD 174.5 million which must be filled urgently to support vulnerable households and farmers during the spring planting season.

metadata.name: Ukraine: FAO Humanitarian response update, 20 April 2023

disasters.summary: This regional synthesis report provides operational policy recommendations on how to ensure education is protected in Asia and the Pacific in the face of climate change and displacement from a human rights-based approach. It focuses on five countries in the region (Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Tuvalu, and Viet Nam) and explores five displacement scenarios and their implications for the right to education. The report aims to inform the development of a Global Report with global policy recommendations.

metadata.name: Asia-Pacific regional synthesis: climate change, displacement and the right to education

disasters.summary: In February 2023, a 7.7 magnitude earthquake struck southern Türkiye and northern Syria, leaving hundreds of thousands of people without access to basic needs and compounding the risks of gender-based violence. In Syria, close to nine million people have been affected, with more than 4.2 million in Aleppo and three million in Idlib. In Türkiye, nearly 50,000 people were killed and tens of thousands more were injured. UNFPA has issued two appeals to fund its responses in Syria and Türkiye, with a combined total ask of $44.5 million, to focus on leaving no one behind and to support humanitarian and recovery efforts.

metadata.name: UNFPA Türkiye/Syria Earthquake Joint Situation Report #3 - 20 April, 2023

disasters.summary: In Nepal, 171 new coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of active cases to 397. President Ramchandra Poudel has been admitted to the hospital due to chest infection.

metadata.name: Focused COVID-19 Media Monitoring, Nepal (April 19, 2023) [EN/NE]

disasters.summary: In 2022, UNHCR delivered USD 977M to 10M people in more than 100 countries in the Asia and Pacific region, with 17 out of 18 operations using cash assistance. Cash transfers are an effective and efficient way of providing much-needed assistance in contexts of insecurity and fragility, and they promote self-reliance among recipients. Almost 68 per cent of households in the region indicated a preference for cash assistance, and it remains the preferred modality of assistance.

metadata.name: UNHCR Regional Bureau for Asia and Pacific (RBAP): 2022 Cash-Based Interventions in the Region

disasters.summary: In March 2023, the Israeli authorities increased the number of exit permits for work purposes, allowing 51,153 exits of people from Gaza. 88% of the exits were for work-related purposes, while 6% were for medical treatment in the West Bank or Israel. More goods entered Gaza, while fewer goods exited.

metadata.name: Movement in and out of Gaza: update covering March 2023

disasters.summary: This week, Somalia is expecting moderate to heavy rainfall in the south, light rainfall in the northwest, and dry conditions in the central and northeastern regions. Last week, 43 stations recorded at least 1 mm of rainfall, with the most intense rains observed in Gatiiley (44 mm/day), Mogadishu (45.5 mm/day) and Hargeisa (59 mm/day). This week, heavy rainfall of between 100 mm and 150 mm is expected in some areas of southern Somalia, while moderate rainfall of between 50 mm and 100 mm is expected over Middle Juba region, several areas in central and southern Gedo, eastern, southern and western Lower Juba region, central and western parts of Bay region, western and eastern coastal parts of Lower Shabelle region, and southwestern parts of Middle Shabelle region. Dry conditions are expected in central and northern parts of the country, while moderate temperatures of between 24°C and 28°C are expected in north and eastern parts of the country.

metadata.name: Somalia Weekly Weather Forecast - Valid From 19th to 25th April 2023

disasters.summary: This brief discusses the challenges faced by waste-pickers, particularly women, in developing nations due to the COVID-19 pandemic. It draws from evidence on demographic, employment, identification, housing and social security characteristics of waste pickers from ten states in India and provides policy directions to ensure structural transformation towards resilient and equitable development for this cohort.

metadata.name: UNDP Development Future Series: Who picks (y)our waste? Evidence-based observations and policy priorities for equitable development

disasters.summary: In 2023, Yemen remains one of the world’s largest humanitarian crises, with 21.6 million people requiring assistance and 80% of the population struggling to access food, water, and health services. Women and girls are bearing the brunt of the crisis, with 1 million women estimated to deliver in 2023 and 1 million women wanting to use family planning to postpone or avoid pregnancy at risk of unwanted pregnancies. UNFPA is appealing for US$70 million to sustain programmes for women and girls in Yemen, but only 12% of this funding appeal has been received by March 2023. In the first three months of the year, UNFPA's response has reached nearly half a million individuals with life-saving reproductive health services, protection information and services, and emergency relief.

metadata.name: UNFPA Response in Yemen, Issue #1 Jan-Mar 2023

disasters.summary: The ETC in the Pacific, led by the World Food Programme (WFP), is supporting the government-led emergency response to Tropical Cyclones Judy and Kevin which hit Vanuatu on 1 and 3 March 2023, as well as two 6.6 and 5.4 magnitude earthquakes which occurred on 3 March 2023. An ETC officer from WFP has installed a satellite data terminal at the Tafea Provincial Emergency Operations Centre (PEOC) and briefed staff at the Vanuatu Meteorology and Geo-Hazards Department on the configuration, activation, and use of Starlink satellite data devices. 251,000 people have been affected by the two cyclones, leaving them without food, power, shelter, and telecommunications. Road network accessibility has been restored to approximately 90%, while emergency relief flights and commercial flights are operating at 80% and 70% of baseline respectively. UNELCO continues to work to repair and restore the national power grid.

metadata.name: Vanuatu - earthquake and cyclones emergency etc ETC Situation Report #6 (Reporting period: 13/04/2023 to 19/04/2023)

disasters.summary: The Earthquake Technical Support (ETS) is providing assistance to the Government of Türkiye in response to the earthquakes that have displaced 3 million people. During the reporting period of 04/04/2023 to 17/04/2023, the ETS trained four Security Operations Centre (SOC) staff to operate the SOC in Gaziantep, conducted assessments in temporary settlements in Adiyaman, Malatya, and Kahramanmaraş to identify needs for additional charging stations, and is currently evaluating technical and financial proposals received from vendors for 60 charging station units with solar power. 40 charging stations will be installed in temporary settlements in Hatay and a further 20 units in Malatya, Adiyaman and Kahramanmaraş.

metadata.name: Türkiye - Earthquake response - ETS Situation Report #9 (Reporting period: 04/04/2023 to 17/04/2023)

disasters.summary: UNICEF and partners are responding to the multiple earthquakes that have hit parts of Syria and Turkey, resulting in 6,000 deaths and 12,000 injuries. 8.8 million people, including 3.7 million children, are affected and in need of water, shelter, food, and emergency medical and psychosocial assistance. 97,400 households have been displaced, and 10,600 buildings have been damaged or destroyed. UNICEF and partners are providing social behavior change messages, psychosocial support, mental health and psychological first aid, and cash assistance to affected families.

metadata.name: UNICEF Syria Humanitarian Situation Report No. 8 (Earthquake): 29 March - 11 April 2023

disasters.summary: Heavy rains in Peru have caused flooding, landslides, and mudslides, affecting 246,813 people and leaving 42,136 homeless. Approximately 517,000 people have urgent humanitarian needs, and 1,056 districts have been declared a state of emergency. Access to humanitarian response is a challenge due to road infrastructure damage, and the cost of reactivating the economy and responding to the emergency is estimated at US$3.1 billion. Humanitarian partners are providing hot meals, food kits, and emergency cash transfers to affected areas.

metadata.name: Peru: Flooding and Landslides Situation Report No. 03 - English Summary (As of 13 April 2023)

disasters.summary: In February 2023, UNHCR El Salvador provided assistance to 374 individuals through their helpline, 212 people at their Support Spaces, and 7,024 people through their Mobile Units. 306 households (980 individuals) at heightened risk received cash assistance to cover basic needs. 171 people were registered with biometrics, and 8% of UNHCR’s financial requirements for El Salvador were received. Highlights included a commitment to strengthen CODER, a community forum with indigenous women, two sessions with government institutions and partner organizations, a virtual public informative session, and a workshop with delegates from CUBOS community centres and the Support Spaces.

metadata.name: UNHCR El Salvador Operational Update #2 - February 2023

disasters.summary: This weekly report provides an overview of the rainfall, water levels, and drought conditions in the Lower Mekong River Basin from April 11-17, 2023. Rainfall was observed in some areas, while temperatures are expected to be warm and rainfall below average for the next 7 days. Water levels at most monitoring stations are below their long-term average value, except at Luang Prabang, Savannakhet, Stung Treng, Kratie and Koh Khel. Drought conditions remain in some areas in the upper, middle, and lower parts of the basin. April is forecasted to receive average rainfall, while May is likely to be severely dry in the 3S area and moderately dry in the south-east.

metadata.name: Weekly Dry Season Situation Report in the Lower Mekong River Basin - 11-17 April 2023

disasters.summary: This policy brief examines the issue of child marriage in Bangladesh, India and Nepal, which is rooted in gender inequality and sustained by cultural and social norms, poverty and lack of opportunities. Governments, civil society organizations and non-profit organizations have been working to curb the issue, and the South Asia Initiative to End Violence Against Children (SAIEVAC) was adopted by all three countries as a plan of action. Additionally, the use of digital technologies and social media platforms has been leveraged to raise awareness and compel individuals and organizations to take action. Quilt.AI has partnered with the UNFPA Asia Pacific Regional Office to build an effective communication and advocacy strategy against child marriage and Gender-Biased Sex Selection (GBSS) in Asia.

metadata.name: Policy Brief: South Asia - Digital Ecosystem Analysis on Child Marriage in Bangladesh, India and Nepal

disasters.summary: In Afghanistan, 20 million people are projected to be acutely food-insecure between November 2022 and March 2023, including 6 million in IPC Phase 4 (Emergency). 4 million people are acutely malnourished, including 3.2 million children under the age of 5. 28.3 million people require multi-sectoral humanitarian assistance in 2023. WFP is negotiating with de facto authorities to enable female national and NGO staff to work, and female beneficiaries to access humanitarian distributions. Hunger is driven by the economic crisis, conflict, climate shocks, and restrictions on women's rights. Afghanistan is the fourth most at-risk country for humanitarian crises and disasters, and the eighth most vulnerable to climate change.

metadata.name: WFP Afghanistan: Situation Report, 17 April 2023

disasters.summary: This paper examines the evidence and data collection related to technology-facilitated violence against women. It highlights the positive and negative gendered impacts of the digital revolution, and the gaps in our understanding of the scale and manifestations of technology-facilitated violence against women. The paper also outlines the methodological, ethical, and sociopolitical challenges to collecting data on technology-facilitated violence against women, and proposes actions for strengthening knowledge generation and data collection.

metadata.name: Technology-facilitated violence against women: Taking stock of evidence and data collection

disasters.summary: UNHCR Romania has provided an update on the Ukraine refugee situation in Romania. As of April 2, 2023, 126,711 refugees have been granted temporary protection in Romania, with 107,706 refugees currently in the country. UNHCR and partners have provided cash assistance to 17,484 refugees in 2023 and 43,129 in 2022, as well as protection counselling services and legal support to 23,954 refugees in 2023 and 65,000 since 2022. The government has approved a new Emergency Ordinance modifying the so-called 50/20 programme which has covered accommodation and food costs of refugees from Ukraine. UNHCR has distributed core-relief items to over 1,300 refugees from Ukraine.

metadata.name: UNHCR Romania: Ukraine Refugee Situation Update, Update #42, 12 April 2023

disasters.summary: This presentation highlights the increasing cases of AWD in Jubaland and Southwest Somalia, with a particular focus on Bellet Hawa in week 14. Response and coordination efforts include bi-weekly TWG meetings, Trocaire's operational response, WHO's supply of materials to at-risk locations, and intensified national-level coordination between WHO and UNICEF.

metadata.name: Somalia: Cholera outbreak Jubaland and Southwest Week 1-14 (13.04.2023) [presentation]

disasters.summary: This document provides an overview of the escalating needs in Lebanon in 2023, produced in collaboration with the Lebanon Humanitarian Country Team and humanitarian partners. It outlines an analysis of the most pressing humanitarian and stabilization needs in the country, and the estimated number of people who need humanitarian assistance. The analysis covers the period from April 2022 to January 2023 and is based on primary data collected through the Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment and Vulnerability Assessment of Syrian Refugees in Lebanon. The document uses the terms “persons displaced from Syria”, “displaced Syrians”, “persons registered as refugees by UNHCR”, “Palestinian refugees in Lebanon”, and “Palestinian refugees from Syria” to refer to those affected by the crisis.

metadata.name: Escalating needs in Lebanon | A 2023 overview

disasters.summary: The number of reported COVID-19 cases in the Philippines has been increasing from 27 Feb - 9 Apr 2023, with 1,944 cases reported in the last week (1.7 cases per 100,000 population). The three regions with the highest reported case counts were the National Capital Region (642 cases), Region IV-A: CALABARZON (204 cases), and Region XI: Davao Region (193 cases).

metadata.name: Philippines Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) Situation Report #125, 10 Apr 2023

disasters.summary: The Pacific Syndromic Surveillance System Weekly Bulletin for Week 15 of 2023 (April 3-April 9) reported alerts for 1 case of Varicella in Wallis & Futuna, 1 case in Fiji, and 2 cases in Vanuatu for AFR, as well as COVID-19 cases in the Cook Islands, RMI, CNMI, FSM, Niue, and Palau, and Dengue-like Illness in Samoa and Vanuatu.

metadata.name: Pacific Syndromic Surveillance System Weekly Bulletin / Système de Surveillance Syndromique dans le Pacifique - Bulletin Hebdomadaire: W15 2023 (Apr 03-Apr 09)
